For a millisecond, he considered throwing her on the bed and fucking her hard and fast, hands clutching her tender waist, hips ramming her rippling thighs, shaft driving into her glistening lips. Tugging the shorn ends off her shoulders and from between her legs, he tossed them on the bed.

“Listen, baby. I’m dead serious. You will follow my directions, exactly as I say and without pause. No questions. I’ll explain later. Do you understand?”

“Are we in danger?” Her look hardened, but a turbulent pulse raced through her slender neck. Her calm was surface.

Getting her to safety was the first order of business. Repressing an ache in his gut, he opted for the most time-effective response. He lied.

“No,” he said, shaking his head and smiling in reassurance. “Just do as I say for now. Ok?”

She searched his eyes, then nodded in acquiescence. “Ok. What do you want me to do?”

“Get dressed,” he repeated, and kissed her quickly. Then he was moving, adrenaline pulsing, mind flashing through the fifty things he needed to accomplish in the next eighteen minutes, filtering them down to only the necessities. “Skip underwear, socks, whatever. We’ll gather our things, but just in case, we have to be ready to walk out the door in sixty seconds.”

She complied as he swiped a pair of silk Cucinelli trousers off the back of a chair and jammed his legs into them, and following his own direction, skipped his boxers. Carefully zipping the fly, he toed his shoes from beneath the nightstand.

“Get all your things in your bag,” he directed, looping and buckling his belt as he shoved his bare feet into the shoes. “Don’t bother sorting, and don’t miss anything. Then make the bed.”

“Make the bed?” She frowned at him as she positioned an Herrera skirt at her feet, long legs shimmering.

Smirking, he slipped a cotton tee over his torso. “You do know how to make a bed?”

She gave him an acrid scowl, lashes fluttering. “No, I only know how to mess it.”

“You are very good at that, yes,” he grinned, grabbing the safety scissors and dropping them in the case.

“When was the last time you made your own bed?” said Hermes, pulling a sheer apricot blouse rightside-in and throwing it over her head.

“This morning,” he replied, momentarily distracted by watching her shimmy into her clothes. He shook himself out of it and set the last implements into the case, snapping it shut. Taking to his feet, he stood the case at the foot of the bed,and gave her a swat on the ass on his way past her to the bathroom. “Just do it, please.”

Snatching a towel off the floor, he laid it atop the suds. With a single swipe of his forearm, he  scraped all the candles off the ledge onto the floating towel. It sank immediately into the water, snuffing out the flames. No lingering wick smoke, and the wet towel would capture any spilled wax. Clean and efficient. He’d take it out once the tub was empty.

A drug dealer. She might have only been half-serious, but he saw the suspicion in her cool look.

“I’m not a fucking criminal,” he muttered, knowing that if they found him, his protests would amount for shit. He ran his fingers through his hair, swearing under his breath, then flipped the lever for the drain and was back on his feet.

“Don’t bother being neat,” he said, returning to the bedroom with her wheeled luggage in tow. He unzipped it and dropped it open on the floor. “Just toss everything in.”

“Okay.”

Yanking open the top dresser drawer, he took out his father’s watch, where he’d set it for safekeeping. He slipped it on his wrist, checking it as he headed for the kitchen. Sixteen minutes, forty-seven seconds.

“Get your shoes on first, Hermes. Be ready to drop what you’re doing and walk out the door.”

“On it,” she sighed testily, fishing beneath the bed for one of her heels. He couldn’t blame her peevishness, she had no idea what was happening or why, and like him, still thrumming with unresolved sexual frustration. An explanation would not likely put her at ease, and with no time for it anyway, he settled for feeling guilty instead.

Moving with measured speed, he tore through the kitchen to clear it of all signs of recent activity. The turnpike was their ticket to freedom. He needed to make the Wild Badger believe the house’s occupants had just run out, and wait for them to return rather than give chase. Spying a coupon ad on the counter from a local restaurant, he ripped one out and left the page sitting in plain sight, then flipped on the TV in the den.

Five minutes later, eleven twenty-two to go, he hustled back into the bedroom, flicking off the hall light behind him. Hermes had the bed made, and rushed past him with an armful of expensive toiletries.

“You’re doing great, baby. Just drop that in the case,” he said, rushing past her, “we have to move quick.”

“Yeah, I got that,” said Hermes, amid a clatter of bottles.

“Good. Go dry the floor and the tub,” he stopped to shove a wayward sock into the dresser and snapped the drawer shut. “Wrap the candles in the towel and bring it back with you.” He didn’t slow to see if she complied, but guessed she’d be scowling at his back for being ordered around like a servant. He hurried into the walk-in.

The night before they’d attended an elite, white tie gala in Newport, at a palatial chateau reminiscent of Versailles, owned by one of Hermes’ fashion mogul friends. She waylaid the gala in a twelve-thousand-dollar gold-beaded McQueen, highlighting every eye-popping curve that had once made her an icon. She hadn’t brought the protective muslin zip-bag with her, though, and the vinyl one draped next to it wouldn’t do. It glittered like Monroe’s Kennedy dress hanging in a linen closet. Steeling himself, he plucked it off the bar, impressed at its weight, along with the matching clutch and strappy Manolos, draped it over his forearm and strode back to the bedroom. Rifling through his tasks in his head, he checked the time. Eight minutes, sixteen seconds remaining.

Hopefully, folding the gown wouldn’t damage it. They needed to travel light, without juggling loose handfuls of stuff, so he placed the shoes and clutch off to one side of the luggage, folded the gown and set it gently across the rest of her things. He strapped it in with a tie to keep it in place and mitigate crumpling.

Hermes scurried in from the bathroom with a soaking lump of wet towel held out in front of her. “Shit-shit-shit, it’s dripping! Where do I put it!”

Damn. It would have to be carried separate. He hopped to his feet to grab the laundry bag. “We’ll put it in the bag, let me go—”

She plopped the bundle into the suitcase with relief, stopping him in his tracks.

He winced at the sodden mass of towel and candle wax lumped heavily atop the McQueen. It sparkled once, flaunting its betrayal. Hermes flicked water off her hands in annoyance, then caught his gaze and followed it back to the luggage. She shot him a blasphemous glare.

“Is that my gown!”

Dammit. “A little starch, it’ll be good as new?” he quipped weakly.

Her scowl could melt a brick. “Why’d you say put it in the bag!”

With a grim sigh, he knelt and scooped up the towel. “I meant the laundry bag,” he said, darting into the walk-in and returning a moment later with the dripping mass tucked safely in a vinyl duffel. He dumped it back in the luggage and zipped it shut.

Hermes squawked with indignation. “Are you just going to—”

“Just send me the bill,” he said pointedly, and snatched his blazer off the back of a chair.

“That’s going to be a ten thousand dollar bill.”

Grimacing, he fished out the keyfob for his Aston Martin and clicked the remote start. The V12 growled aggressively to life from the driveway out front. Turning to Hermes, he held the blazer out for her to step in.

“I’m sorry about your gown, baby,” he said, as she shoved herself into the proffered sleeves, blanketed in its swimming folds. Grasping her firmly by the nape, he kissed her brow gently, and pulled her forehead to his. “But seeing you in it was worth ten times what it cost.” And he’d ruin a thousand McQueens before he saw anything happen to her.

Hermes smiled weakly, then drew back, squinching her eyes with concern. “Where’s Duchess?”

The cat. Shit. He checked his watch again. Six minutes, forty-nine seconds.

“Check the bedrooms,” he said, “I’ll go look in the front of the house.”

Racing now, he snatched the carrier out of the hall closet. He hurried through the rooms, peeking under tables and chairs, calling with soft kss-kss noises. Duchess had taken up hiding beneath the sofa, cleaning herself indignantly. Crouched down on all fours, he tried to woo her out gently, but cats being egotistical creatures, she only stared at him disdainfully. With the clock ticking, he gave up on chivalry, grabbed her gently by the scruff and scooched her into the carrier.

“Your carriage awaits, your Majesty,” he soothed, ignoring her rancorous growl and latching the wire gate shut.

Beyond the front door, the black V-12 Vanquish crouched in the brick circle drive, moonlight playing on its glossy curves, ready to launch. Even sitting still it looked like it was breaking the speed limit. For a moment, the turnpike didn’t seem that far away. But it occurred to him that two hundred thirty miles an hour wouldn’t matter for dick if they showed up with drones.

Was he really at that level? Were they just coming to arrest him, or sending snipers? And what about Hermes? Merely at the wrong place at the wrong time, but still an accomplice for all they knew. If they were bringing him in, likely they’d just question and release her quietly. They were after him, not her. But if they were coming to take him out…

Careful not to jostle the cat, he hurried back to the bedroom.

“Oh thank god,” sighed Hermes. “I was worried she might be hiding.”

“Holding court, more like,” he said, offering the carrier. Taking it, she peered inside, reassuring Duchess with soft noises in her native Albanian Tosk. He smiled at the tenderness of the moment, but they had to leave, now. “Let’s get to the car.”

“Ok,” she said, adjusting the coat on her frame.

“I’m right behind you.” He gave her arm a gentle squeeze as she stepped past him into the hall.

Grabbing his hard-case and the luggage, he performed a rapid check of the bedroom. No apparent traces of their passing remained. Frowning at that thought, he killed the lights and hurried behind Hermes to the foyer.

As they reached the front door, a pair of headlights slowed at the end of the driveway. Lunging, he plastered Hermes into the nook next to the door, pressing her hard against the wall. A rush of air escaped her, either a protest or a response from the impact. Duchess mewled softly, the carriage trapped between them. He hit the light switch with an elbow, and glanced at his watch.

One minute, thirty-eight.

The foyer remained dark, moonlight throwing tall shadows from the panes on the hardwood. Had the car turned into the drive, its beams would have sliced through the door’s oval glass. He risked a peek. It had already moved past the driveway and continued down the road. His pulse eased, still racing. They had to move. The Vanquish was their best option. A 6-figure getaway car.

“What’s going on?” Hermes whispered, her mouth a breath away from his ear.

“Listen,” he said, keeping his voice calm, but commanding. Dominant. “A car went by. I don’t think it was them, but I don’t—”

“Who the hell is them?”

Growling, he dropped the case, grasped the back of her neck, and pulled her forehead against his. He lamented pulling Dom, but her unquestioning compliance was vital, and her conditioned response to submission might ease her anxiety. He was in control, and would handle anything that might arise.

“Hermes, I need you to listen to me, no questions.”

For all he knew, there could be a dozen operatives converging on the house at this very moment, tactical silhouettes ghosting through the darkness, communicating objectives with clipped, kinesic gestures, black barrels seeking their targets with thin red lasers.

Her brown eyes flamed with defiance. “Let me guess, out of bounds?”

“Dammit, Hermes,” he snarled, “now is not the time, I’ll explain later. You will follow instructions, do you understand?”

“Fine!”

“Lower your voice. And thank you.” Easing his hold on her, he dug into his pocket for his phone. 

“If anything happens, the unlock code is a clockwise spiral.” He showed her with his thumb, and the phone surged to life. “Dial star, nine-nine, star. When the voice answers, you say ‘Jacqueline, respond’. Say it back to me.”

“Jacqueline, respond,” she said, a shadow drawing across her brow.

“Good. The voice will say ‘Acknowledged’, and reply with a woman’s name beginning with an ‘R’, like Rita or Rachael. When he does, you say ‘Alpha down, assist’. Say it now.”

“Alpha down?” Her eyes widened, agitation giving over to fear. “That means you.”

“Alpha down, assist,” he repeated firmly, impressing the point. “Then do exactly as he says.”

“But what if he doesn’t respond with a woman’s name?”

“Starting with an R…”

“Yeah, okay. But what if he doesn’t?”

If he didn’t, that meant both he and Jay had been compromised, and she was on her own. Hermes wasn’t their target, though, highly unlikely anything would come of it for her. The men out there weren’t criminals, they were federal agents, too.

“He’ll answer.”

“What if—”

“No more questions,” he commanded. The minute was over. Zero time. “When I tell you, get to the car as fast as you can, understand?”

“Yes, okay.”

He kissed her hard, every vessel and artery in his body thundering. Her lips were warm and soft, her tentative hand on his forearm galvanizing his resolve. He gave himself half a second to look into her beautiful brown eyes again, to memorize every lash.

Casually, though his heart threatened to jettison from his throat, he opened the door and stepped out, intentionally pausing to futz with the doorhandle. If there were snipers, this was their chance. They could take him down without any danger to Hermes.

He blinked, the searing heat of a bullet smashing into his brain and the empty blackness of infinity… didn’t come. He exhaled sharply.

Lifting his head, he did a quick scan of the grounds. No SWAT. No assassins. No black-swathed figures slipping through the shadows as quiet as dreamless sleep. Flexing his jaw and swallowing the rock in his throat, he motioned to Hermes.

“Don’t run,” he said quietly, “just move quickly.”

Eyes wider than the full moon beaming through the trees, she nodded and slipped past him, stumbling over the threshold. He caught her elbow and steadied her, then grabbed the luggage and pulled the door shut with a foot. He caught her up with a few long strides, positioning himself in front of her, and led the rest of the way to the car, eyes trained on the shadowy grounds.

He jammed the luggage and case in the meager trunk, and hopped in. The Vanquish rumbled beneath him, dash lit up like a fighter jet. Hermes righted herself from securing Duchess on the floorboard behind her seat. He caught a flash of her eyes as she settled into the leather, a vulnerability in them that hadn’t been apparent in the house, highlighted by the dim glow of the dashboard.

“Seatbelt,” he said, gruffly, so that his voice didn’t crack. Reaching across the console, he wrapped his hand around hers as she fumbled with the buckle, and snapped it into place. His insides were slush, as well, but she couldn’t know that.

“Don’t worry,” he said, commanding her gaze. “I got you.”

She nodded, then wiped her nose on her sleeve. “Shit,” she laughed nervously. “I can’t believe I just did that.”

“Your secret’s safe with me, beautiful,” he smiled. Buckling his own belt, he tapped the paddle to shift into gear and crept down the drive.

“We’re going to go fast, Hermes. Are you okay with speed?”

She nodded off-handedly. “Just get us out of here.”

“Roger that, Miss Bizjak,” he agreed, easing the Martin into the street. He would have preferred to tear out of the driveway and jump on it, but this was an exclusive neighborhood, with only this one narrow road out. Best to remain inconspicuous.

“If you start to feel light-heated or motion sickness,” he said, watching the tree line keenly, “or if I tell you to duck, don’t argue. Cross your arms on your lap and duck your head down.”

She grunted in annoyance, but didn’t reply.

“Hermes,” he said reassuringly, “I understand you’re pissed. That’s fine, but I need you to answer. If I—”

“Ok,” she said flatly.

He wished he could take the time to console her or to explain, but as they rounded a corner, a gold sedan crept past them in the opposite direction. He watched in his mirror, gritting his teeth. As they swept into the curve, their brake lights flared red. It must be them. They’d be pulling into the drive, quickly slipping up to the dark house. How long until they determined it was empty and made a decision on whether or not to wait there? A minute? Two? A few more blocks separated him from the open road.

“You’re not going very fast,” said Hermes tersely, leaning forward in her seat, hands on her lap, eyes scanning every bush and dark form.

“Not yet,” he said levelly, despite his blood thundering in his head. “When we get to the highway.”

She drew a deep, shuddering breath. Her bun had come almost completely undone, the drying wisps of her hair silver in the moonlight. He wondered briefly if she’d keep the blazer.

The Vanquish prowled through the corridor of trees, a panther prowling the jungle. A minute later, they reached the stop sign at Pike Road. Much as he wanted to, he still couldn’t screech off. He’d have to get at least a mile away to ensure the Feds wouldn’t hear the roar of the twelve-cylinder beast beneath the hood.

He eased out onto the pavement, headed west. 88 North was only a few hundred feet away, and plenty of open road he could use to quickly put distance between them.

“A mile or two,” he told Hermes, “then we’re off. Okay?”

She nodded.

“Breathe, baby,” he told her. She gave him a thin smile, and took a long breath.

He watched his rearview as they drew up to the 88 junction. Turning north towards I-195, he dug his Bluetooth earpiece out of the console. Jay had been waiting through twenty-four interminable minutes of radio silence. He’d be worried sick.

“Hermes, plug my phone in, would you please?”

“Sure,” she breathed, fishing it of the coat pocket. “Glad to get rid of it.”

He clipped the Bluetooth to his ear. Not much longer now. His stomach tightened at what that probably meant. The phone lit up as she dropped it in its carrier, and he thumbed the call button on the steering wheel.

“Call. Jay. Office.”

Hermes cast a peculiar look in his direction as the Vanquish acknowledged and dialed. Jay picked up before the first ring ended.

“JR?” Jay’s voice was wired tight.

“Yeah.”

“Are you clear?”

“Uncertain. Ten minutes.”

“Shit, ok,” he sighed heavily, likely running his fingers through his thick, snowy curls and adjusting his glasses. “How’s Hermes?”

“She’s doing great,” he said, smiling at her. “Tell me what happened.”

“Large transfer came through the pipe, flared the monitors. Were you expecting 60k?”

Hermes fidgeted with her hair, tucking loose spirals back up into her bun. It must have been her. The contract was nearly up, she was likely hoping to extend it. He hadn’t been expecting it, but he’d given explicit instructions on how to make money transfers without violating restrictions under the Patriot Act. Why hadn’t she followed them? She glanced at him furtively, concern in her eyes.

Shit. Hermes had just become a liability.

He turned back to the road with a quiet sigh. “No, I wasn’t expecting it, but I’m pretty sure I know what it’s about.”

“Ok, what?”

“Not now. I’ll notify you when I’m clear, and we can discuss the rest later.”

Jay muttered under his breath. “JR. This is big.”

“Have they ID’d me?”

“Your account, yes, but not you. Not yet,” said Jay. The drumming of his fingers on his heavy aluminum desk resounded through his speaker. He was nervous. “I’m on it, and I can head it off, but I’m going to have to think fast to get around a more thorough investigation. Are you trackable?”

Accelerating smoothly, he tapped the paddle to shift into fourth gear. The tension must be feeding the cylinders; the Vanquish seemed just as anxious as he was to tear ass down the road.

If the Feds were being insistent and broke into the house, there likely wasn’t much to find. If they decided to be extra-thorough, however, they could probably trace Hermes through hair and fiber samples. That wasn’t terribly likely.

“Eighty-percent no,” he replied.

Jay grunted. “That’s twenty percent less than certain, damn. Either way, if they don’t find you, the Deputy Director will hear about it. I need to clean this up fast, or HomeSec will be sniffing for a goddamn terrorist first thing tomorrow. Get yourself clear JR, we’ll go from there.”

“Roger, Jolly.”

“Don’t Jolly me,” admonished Jay, “This one’s going to cost you.”

For Jay, that meant a weekend of hockey and late night bureau stories over domestic beer. And a thorough scolding of his dubious lifestyle.

“Understood,” he smirked. At the moment, that sounded blissful. “Will check when clear, JR out.”

“Roger that.”

He tapped his Bluetooth and sighed. Of all the ways a night like tonight might have gone wrong, this scenario hadn’t even crossed his mind. He needed to get Hermes to safety, and start the work of repairing the damage she’d inadvertently caused. What a damn shame, too. They were supposed to have a month left together. By week’s end, he would be a thousand miles away, maybe more, with a new name, new papers, new everything.

Jay would find a way to cover her tracks as well. If anybody could, it was him. Completely off the radar, he would never see her again. But she’d be safe.

“Everything ok?” she asked tentatively.

“Yes,” he said, checking the odometer. They’d gone nearly two miles. He just had to hope there was no drone. “Time to fly.”

“Was it my transfer?”

He paused to pull his cuff over his father’s watch. “Don’t worry about it, baby, I’ve got people on it. It’ll be fine by morning.”

Reaching across the console, he took her hand into his. It felt small in his grip, but he gave her a reassuring squeeze and pulled it to his lips for a gentle kiss. It struck him how thoroughly the human body communicated, so much with so little.

Her mouth lifted as she turned her dark eyes up to his, studying his face intently. She smiled, a subtle curve etched in sorrow. Epiphany often strikes malapropos.

“I’m going to miss you,” she murmured, holding her stoic facade.

His return smile was no stronger than hers, so he opted for the most time-effective response. He nodded.

Yes, he had to set her aloft, a  paper lantern, dammit. He would miss her, too.

“Settle in,” he said, kissing her fingers once more, and returning his grip to the paddle shifters. “We’re gonna go fucking fast.”

The engine roared to life, planting them both into their seats. Inertia stole their breath, and the smooth road disappeared beneath the Vanquish.

Agness, Oregon

Let’s Begin

His current name was Marshall.

Inspired in part by the storied medieval knight, William the Marshall, it was his eleventh name in almost twenty years. He’d taken it a month ago as he uprooted from a nondescript 19th century flat in Boston to a concealed A-frame in remote Agness, Oregon. 

He’d grown up two hours southwest of Chicago, in a claustrophobic town near Starved Rock, Illinois, not unlike Agness. Desolate, drowsy, and a little weird around the edges if you stayed long enough to learn names. Whether he would stay here that long remained to be seen, but for now the isolation was necessary. “Going dark,” Jay had said.

Perched halfway up a mountain, the house jutted out over a boundless forest of oak and conifer. He had nearly forty acres to himself, the majority primeval wilderness, a thirty-six-minute drive from town. He’d timed it. No inquisitive, cookie-laden community members would be encroaching on his front door, a quarter-mile beyond the nameless mailbox. He could slip out the back and disappear in an instant, completely under the radar of prying eyes, electronic or otherwise.

Marshall stepped through the fortressian oak doors, gliding  on iron hinges, silent and stoic, the wisp of his bespoke graphite suit audible as he moved. Timex glinting dully on his wrist, he shifted the ancient leather hard-case from his left hand to his right, guarding it from sight, and shut the door with a stolid clack.

His footsteps reported hollowly as he strode through the empty foyer into the kitchen, his ears still unattuned to the new acoustics. Every small noise reverberated in the virgin space.  Placing the case next to the white marble-topped island, he glanced over the various fabrics and swatches splashed across the counter. Farrow & Ball, Kartell, and a few local, Portland-based catalogs. He dropped his blazer on the back of a stool and studied a yellow invoice sitting atop a pile of papers.

A woman hailed up from the lower level of the house, her voice muffled and desaturated, though the Southern cant rang clear. “Whoever just came in, if you ain’t a six-foot sex beast you can just turn right back ‘round!”

Marshall smiled crookedly and called back, “Good evening, Hedy.”

“Hey, Mr. Jones!” said Hedy’s voice, brighter this time. “Be right up!”

She had known him for five of his names, and after the third, dubbed him ‘Mr. Jones.’ Likely she’d already committed his current last name, Vaughn, to her mental archives, with no intention of recalling it. A talented, independent designer, she and her wife Cynthia were among the first same-sex couples to be married in the state of Georgia. She lived in Atlanta, but flew wherever Marshall needed her, whenever he moved.

Snatching up the invoice, he crossed the kitchen, reading it carefully. Of all the modifications to the house, the kitchen had been the most personal, the previous appliances replaced with industrial, service-level equipment, apportioned and stocked for a chef. Hedy had outdone herself, adding accents of warm wood and brightly-colored cookware to offset acres of stainless steel. Marshall would outdo himself with her bonus.

He cut through the formal dining room branching off the kitchen, as yet unmodified and awaiting marching orders, the double-tap of heel to sole tattooing his gait through the vacant room. A hall beyond opened into a circular landing, a set of floating spiral stairs leading down to the entertainment den, laundry and mini gym, and another, more formal staircase of burnished wood and marble to the upper floor. The master bedroom, the only room that Hedy wouldn’t design, he alone entered it.

The far west end of the dining room opened up into a stunning great room. Paneled walls soared twenty feet to the exposed rafters of the vaulted ceiling, its deep wood floors gleaming in a perpetual flood of light. The morning sun peered through a row of east-facing clerestory windows to start the day, and in the evening sank into a distant mountain ridge beyond a Ship’s Prow of towering glass that stretched floor to ceiling. The prow was one of his favorite features of the house, affording a breathtaking view of green and blue treetops spilling down the mountainside to the Rogue River, at the base of the valley five hundred feet below.

His scrutinizing blue eyes shifted from the invoice to a freshly installed panel in the wall, housing a series of toggle switches. Flicking the endmost with a fingertip, a stainless steel eyebolt lowered gently from a cable in the ceiling, the smooth whir of precision gears just discernible behind the wall. Anchored to reinforced joists, it could hold eleven hundred pounds, one of a ring of eight. Marshall grinned like a jackal. These were going to be fun.

As he returned through the dining room preoccupied with his thoughts[RP, BL], Hedy bustled up the spiral staircase, looking jubilant, her electric-blue pixie cut bouncing. She wore white jeans and her trademark Converse Chucks, baby blue today, a loose gray Moby t-shirt cut into a sort of tank top, and a light blue sports bra beneath.

“Hey,” she sang, gray eyes twinkling in the sunlight from the great room windows. 

“Hello, beautiful,” he replied, folding the invoice and slipping it into a drawer in the island.

“You look nice. As usual. Good day at the office?” she asked shrewdly, tapping at her tablet with enthusiasm as she entered the room. Hedy loved to guess what he did for a living, and though Marshall confirmed nothing, he couldn’t really hide that he clearly did not have a boss, nor report to an office.

“My day is just beginning,” he said simply. “What about yours? Having fun with the place?”

“Funner’n a two-dicked Dachshund,” she grinned, peering up from her tablet briefly. “Gimme a sec and I’ll show ya.”

Marshall laughed appreciatively as Hedy slid a stool under herself with one foot and flopped down on it. Shuffling swatches and catalogs aside to make room, she set the tablet in the newly emancipated space and leaned on a forearm, settling down to business.

“Hungry or thirsty?” asked Marshall, reaching into the liquor cabinet over the in-built chiller and pulling out an ornate bottle of 30-year Cognac and two snifters.

Hedy gave him a skeptical look, three silver rings glinting in her cocked eyebrow. “As in molecules? I’ll pass.”

“That would be molecular gastronomy—”

“Yeah, I know,” she replied, returning to her screen with a snicker, “make me a meatloaf and you got a date.”

“A drink then?”

“Just one, sweetie. I gotta drive.”

Grinning at her reticence to try his cuisine, he splashed a nip for her and slid it across the counter before pouring one for himself. 

Pausing in her task, she studied the snifter a moment, then held it up to inspect it more closely, a smoky blue moonstone in a leafy setting hovering on her pinky. Clearly a new acquisition, though her birthday wasn’t until June, and while birthstones needn’t come only in their allotted month, it added a twinge to the mystery of it. Marshall couldn’t help but wonder if it were a gift from Cynthia, or another friend, or a personal indulgence.

“What a great color,” she said, her eyes seeming to sink into the brandy and swim around. “It’s like wine mixed with liquid sunlight. What do you think about using a creamy brandy color for the sofa, Mr. Jones?”

Brows raised in consideration, Marshall nodded. “Hm. That could work nicely, I think. It’ll add some warmth to the room… not too red, though.”

“No, definitely more caramel.”

“Perfect,” agreed Marshall. “Go for it.”

She toasted him and downed a healthy swig. Eyelids fluttering, her face pickled like a deflating balloon. “Pssh! S’good…” she croaked, sucking cool air across her tongue.

Marshall swirled his glass, stirring the notes of blueberry and hickory, and took a warm, sensual sip. “Napoleon XO,” he offered with a refreshed sigh.

Hedy scoffed. “More like Exxon.”

She drained the rest quickly and smacked the snifter down hard on the marble. Marshall winced, the resounding klawk of glass on glass a tuning fork between his shoulder blades. He busied himself returning the Cognac to the chiller to cover his reaction. Not her issue, she needn’t feel responsible.

“It’s a pretty color,” she said, barking a wheezing cough into the crook of her arm, “but goes down like distilled kerosone.”

With a playful flourish, he spun a bottle of French Burgundy to face her, underscoring the label with a flattened palm. “How about wine instead? Domaine Louis Jadot, very silky. Picked it myself,” he joked.

“Honey, I gotta drive,” she protested. Sliding the tablet in front of him, she tapped an icon, bringing up a series of images of the interior. “Here, take a look.”

Placing his cognac on the counter, softly, he swiped through her designs. Everything was Mid-century Modern in fine, hand-stitched leather, with lots of chrome, and teak veneer. Marshall knew enough about art and design to know what he liked. For the flat in Boston, he wanted exactly three large Helmut Newton prints in the parlor, centered around an overstuffed French blue chaise, and an Elmer Batters on a lone coral wall in the powder room. Hedy enjoyed his particularity and odd specificity when it came to designing his home, she took notes, occasionally throwing in excited comments about this piece or that.

She had left all the art pieces blank, only denoting where each might go and their approximate size. They pored over the selections, and as Moira was a fan of classical paintings as an art student, especially those notable for their specific use of light, Marshall opted for Vermeer’s Procuress, Leighton’s Fisherman and the Syren, and others of a similar ilk. Hedy carefully noted each title and their placements.

An hour later, Marshall wrote a check and saw her to the door.

“You’re way too het for your style,” she chided as she stepped into the foyer.

“I don’t think it’s possible to be more het than I am,” he replied, “I’d much rather admire a blouse than design one.”

“Admire its contents, you mean,” she scoffed.

“I am a sucker for the contents.”

“Yeah, I can relate.”

Marshall choked on a laugh, shaking his head.

“I’m just saying, Mr. Jones, you’re pretty good at design and you totally dress the part.”

“So straight can be stylish?” he teased, pulling her gray hoodie off a hook and helping her into it as though it were a fox fur.

“Sure they can, honey,” she smiled, reaching up and pushing a lazy lock of hair off his forehead, “we’re just better at it.”

“True story,” said Marshall, “and you are the best.”

“Aw,” she waggled her head dismissively.

“And Hedy?” he said, pulling the door open for her.

“Yeah?”

“The Malm fireplace?” He gave her a prescient grin, his tone pointed. “White.”

Glancing at him side-eye, she stepped over the threshold with an airy shrug. “Okay…”

“And by white,” he emphasized, “I mean do not accidentally order gray anyway. Understand?”

“All right!” she protested, holding up her palms in defense. “I mean, it’s not like I’m a designer or anything. What are you even paying me for if you’re gonna pick everything yourself?”

Marshall feigned to ponder the question. “Tasteful execution?”

“Then it should be gray. It’ll pick up the red tones and keep them warm instead of turning them pink. Nothing in that room is cool—”

“Ok,” he said, laughing. “Order both. We’ll debate over them when they arrive, and find a spot for the runner-up.”

Hedy blinked, taken aback. “Really?”

He gave her a crooked grin.

“Cool!” she beamed.

They exchanged a warm hug and peck, the cognac fresh on her lips and DSH Minuit drifting off her collarbone into his nostrils. His maleness stirred, but he jammed it down. He would never make a play for her, for a hundred reasons, not the least of which was her friendship.

“Thanks, Mr. Jones,” she said, hiking her shoulder bag in place. “You’re the best, too.”

“See you in a few weeks,” he replied, and closed the door behind her, enshrouding the place in solitude.

Marshall breathed out, pausing to listen to the hollow wind caressing the sills. The sounds of the house were all new and foreign, every creak and hum stark against a canvas of displacement. For now, he was still a visitor. the soft tension of whether or not the place would embrace him thrummed in his bones.

Faces gathered in the deep, shadowy folds of his mind. Former lovers and ghosts, each hoping that tonight he might entertain them, and each knowing he could not. He set about his business, working to dispel their memories and the vestiges of Hedy’s perfume.

Returning to the kitchen island, he flipped open the lid on his laptop, stripping off his dress shirt as he waited in favor of the white cotton tee beneath. The computer chugged along interminably, so he slipped the Diors off his feet as well and carried them to the foyer. Preoccupied with his thoughts, he yanked off his socks, preferring the feeling of a cool, hard surface beneath his soles. He padded back to the island barefoot, folding them up and setting them carefully atop his shirt and blazer on the stool.

The screen welcomed him, so he made a quick check of his stock portfolio and foreign accounts. Needlessly, since accessing it would trigger a fresh round of scrutiny that he couldn’t afford. Going dark. But for a property in Italy he’d been trying to sell for nearly five years, all he had available was liquid capital, to which the purchase and renovation of the house had made a considerable dent. A bear market was no help, he might be here longer than planned. Flexing his toes against the polished granite tile, he killed that screen and logged on to his IRC channel to check for a response from Moira.

Not that he’d expected her to be signed in yet; he was an hour and fourteen minutes early. Finger-combing his hair, he remonstrated himself for his over-eagerness, and scrolled idly through their previous chats, smiling at where she’d first agreed to hire him a few weeks ago.

Mbeetle | 04/04 | 10:21 pm

Oh whatever, now you’re just flattering. ^__^

User1138 | 04/04 | 10:22 pm

That’s three.

I don’t give false compliments, remember?

Mbeetle | 04/04 | 10:23 pm

Shit really!

User1138 | 04/04 | 10:22 pm

I’ve taught you this lesson once already. 

What is the proper response to a compliment?

Mbeetle | 04/04 | 10:23 pm

Thank you. >_>

User1138 | 04/04 | 10:24 pm

Very good.

So then. Are you ready?

Mbeetle | 04/04 | 10:26 pm

Ugh, I can’t wait

Nervous, but fuck it

Yeah

So ready

Marshall lifted his gaze to the soaring bay windows, meeting his own reflection against a backdrop of twilit forest. He hadn’t turned on any lights, or even noticed that the sun had surrendered the sky to a starlit tableau, a symphonic rasp of katydids in the tall Cascara tree just beyond the deck. The contours and edges of his body illuminated by the blue glow of the laptop, he appeared to float in lotus position before the cosmos.

Moira would throw herself into this new experience like she did everything else, academic and headstrong, intent on her end goal. He would need to be on his game to pull her down out of her head, into her core. To experience with her body, rather than observe with her mind. To feel rather than think.

And then she would be a supernova.

With a grin, he ducked his head and clacked a reply on the keyboard.

User1138 | 04/04 | 10:27 pm

I am absolutely ecstatic, Moira.

And honored that you’ve chosen me.

You will be my Queen, and for your fealty, I will lay the kingdom at your feet.

That said...

Let’s begin.
title: 01 Let’s Begin

content:
two

04.12 02:44 PM

Portland, Oregon

Special Occasion

His Timex watch was from the Seventies. Its expandable silver band pinched at his wrist hair whenever he moved. Edges buffed smooth from forty years of wear, it bore its nicks and scars with dignity, the second hand diligently pacing its thirteen-millionth lap around the face. Marshall wound it absently, unaware of the grooves the tiny ridged knob had etched in his fingertips.

He sat outside at a table for two on the patio cafe next to the open doors, thrown wide for a warm April afternoon. His hawk eyes flicked over a row of large planters exploding with yellow daffodils, to the thrumming foot traffic of the riverwalk, sidling pleasantly along the Willamette River in downtown Portland.

A tall businessman, frustrated with the touristy pace of all the weekenders, muttered under his breath as he darted through the crowd. Two college girls, sisters, judging by their identical swooping eyelids, huddled together over a cell phone as they walked. A man behind them stole an appraising glance at their backsides as they passed. He wouldn’t even notice the loose button on his blazer until he got home.

The ambling procession tweaked Marshall’s senses, too much movement to focus on, so he checked his watch for thirtieth time in an hour. It was 2:44pm, their date set at 3:00. Plenty of time, but the ticking of his watch was the insistent drip-drip of a leaky faucet.

“Damn.”

He spun his jack-and-coke rhythmically clockwise, always clockwise, the cool condensation on the glass pooling along his fingertips. Tapping them on the cloth napkin, still neatly folded next to the wine list, he leaned forward, crossing his arms on the table, and waited. Adrenaline thrummed in his blood in a steady trickle, like the glistening rivulets on his drink.

What if she broke the Eighteen Minute Rule on the very first date?

He’d cancel. He’d have to.

She would be so completely infuriated, and rightly so, she’d fly straight back home. And that would be the end of it. Over before it even started.

He and Moira had not yet spoken, only chatted. He wanted to hear her voice for the first time in person, pristine, not as a feeble analog. Deconstructed, compressed, and projected from a tinny speaker. He wanted the air they shared, drawn into her warm lungs, reformed by the vibrations of her throat, carved into thoughts by her lips, seeping past his eardrums into his mind, where he would take possession of them. The consumption of another soul, refactoring who he was to include her.

But if she were late, and he canceled, the only thing he’d likely hear her say was “Fine, fuck you, asshole,” and then she’d storm out.

It was 2:45.

His suit had arrived from Paris two days before. Between the plane tickets, the trip, and the suit itself, he was hemorrhaging enough money to buy another car. He could have just ordered and shipped from Barney’s New York, and it would have been sufficient, but his first impression needed to be more than merely sufficient. He would have paid ten times as much if he’d had to.

Crafted to his body in polished titanium silk, it traced his physique as though a sculptor had chiseled it from the marble of his own flesh. The muted plum pocket square matched the tie, bold against a starched, white shirt of Egyptian cotton, tied in a Trinity knot and pinned with a tasteful gold clip. Strapped Gucci oxblood boots completed the ensemble, and both the bartender and a tall redhead had given him a double-take as he walked in. He’d gleaned from chats that Moira preferred a sleek, classic look, and the tailor hit it right on the head, even adjusting the seams so that it bunched in exactly the right places.

Portland lay three hours of twisting mountain and coastal roads from Ashland. He’d arrived a bit early for check-in, 10:27 this morning, hard-case in hand, thrumming with anticipation. The concierge had graciously escorted him to the room, with two handsome young bellhops in impeccable uniforms directly behind with the rest of his bags. If he needed anything at all, Cesar was available at the touch of a button.

Moira had chosen the Presidential Suite, which, as advertised, was indeed stately enough for a President. Tasteful, gilt-framed paintings graced every wall, its floors laid in ultra-dense carpet, and everywhere an abundance of dark, polished wood. It boasted a dining area and office, a cavernous bath, its own private balcony, and of course an expansive bedroom, with a king-sized poster bed draped in luxurious coverings.

He’d had Cesar send the bellhops to remove all but two of its chairs, then retired a garish iron centerpiece from the dining table to the closet with a disdainful frown. He’d ordered four vases of white tulips and narcissus in its place, and then dinner, which would be sent upon his request. A dispatch had been sent to fulfill his fruit, wine and whiskey selections, or more accurately, Moira’s. While the room might be fit for a President, today it had to be fit for a Queen.

Finally, he dragged a spare end table to the bedside, opened the case, and laid out the tools of his trade, each piece master-crafted, works of art collected diligently over twenty years and six countries. He inspected and tested each, slapping them against his palm or bare forearm, pleased with their sting.

He’d taken lunch on the balcony, more of necessity than enjoyment of the hotel’s white glove service. Then he dressed, with attention to detail, and came down to the table by 2:04.

On first entering the hotel bar, a pang of anxiety had lodged in his chest. Marshall didn’t do restaurants. Instead he’d chosen the patio, shifting the chairs so that he could see through the bar to the stately lobby. He wanted to witness her entrance. Scanning his surroundings, he also noted and memorized all the exits, public, emergency and staff.

Tea failed to narcotize his anticipation, so the bartender, sensing his discomfiture, had brought him a stiff drink and a dazzling smile. Both on the house. Warm and charming, on another day, he would have pondered her lush bottom at length. Today, however, all he had to offer her was a generous tip. He saw only Moira’s wild curls and intelligent, cognac eyes. And if he allowed his mind to wander, she became tangled and panting in crisp cotton sheets, or slipping out of the tub, oiled water cascading in runnels down her belly, dipping into her navel and glistening in the valleys of her thighs.

2:47. Sunlight sparkled through the sweating carafe of ice water, projecting shafts of light onto the sleek steel case of his phone.

A brunette in a white wool cardigan cast a number of furtive glances at him from behind her compact. The chair across from her sat empty, and though she didn’t hurry to look away, he caught a twinge of self-conscious guilt when she finally did. Her date arrived, and she made a concerted effort afterward to keep her eyes focused forward.

Marshall twisted the napkin under his drink, aligning it with the edge of the table, and returned his gaze to the riverwalk. A young family passed, dad pushing a bag-laden stroller while a rambunctious toddler circled Mama’s pretty legs. One hand shoved in his mouth, the other on her thigh, his impish face was a mess of smeared chocolate. Mama wiped at his cheek with a thumb, licking her finger clean and trying again, but nothing short of a fire hose would suffice for that task. Marshall caught himself smiling. Swallowing hard to clear the knot in his throat, he adjusted the cuff over his father’s watch and glanced towards the lobby entrance again.

And without warning, she was there.

Sheathed in a silky cocktail dress the color of sunlit copper, liquid and undulating in the light, she stood in the bar entrance, fidgeting with a matching clutch, held close to her tummy in both hands. Nervous, or perhaps excited, she scanned the bar, spry curls swaying with her movements. The rich fabric of the dress gathered in a rosette over her right shoulder, with a boat neck that swooped gently across her collarbone. It clung to her figure in mesmerizing folds that wrapped around her body, draping from her hips and breasts, tucking suggestively into the shadowed valleys of her cleavage and between her thighs. He couldn’t pick a curve on which to focus, his eyes stumbled over themselves trying to drink all of her at once.

She was fucking beautiful.

Her eyes caught his, hitting him like a tidal wave. A siren’s gaze, staring, threatening to capture him. He couldn’t turn away. Her expression softened, lips spreading in a pixie smile with a pronounced kink at the corners. The whole room seemed to pull towards her, a radiant copper sun whose gravity would not be denied.

Dazed, he composed himself, then got to his feet and strode through the doors towards her. A man in a camel blazer gawped openly as she passed his table, his wife harumphing sharply to redirect his wandering attention. Unaware, Moira moved past them, her gait elegant and certain, polished toes tucked prettily into copper stilletos, whose serpentine straps curled around the delicate bones of her feet like an art nouveau ribbon.

Her perfume swept over him first, musky and earthy, intoxicating as bourbon, with notes of leather and wood. He didn’t recognize it, except that it smelled like her. A deep arousal thrummed from his groin to the tips of his ears, hunger quickening within him. He took a steadying breath and smiled.

“Hello, Marshall,” said Moira.

His breath evaporated.

Her voice was an iris petal, with a surprising strength that defied explanation. Sturdy, smooth, seductive. Axiomatic. Every law in the universe had sprung into play; gravity, inertia, attraction. He groaned under his breath.

Fucking hell, he was in trouble.

“Moira”, he grinned crookedly.

With a nervous, buoyant laugh, she offered her hand. “Nice to meet you.”

“Finally,” he said, taking her fingers in his own and kissing her lightly on the cheek. His lips met her skin with an electric charge.

Over a head taller than her, he caught a glimpse of the back of her dress. There wasn’t one; her dress scooped out past the base of her spine, offering the slightest hint of the swell of her bottom. Marshall nearly shot through his zipper. Stifling a growl, he reminded himself that they were in public. He wanted to sweep the nearby table clean and take her on the spot, hard and fast before the china even hit the floor.

He needed to regain control. Now. They paused and stared at each other, his shoulders like concrete, hands itching to touch her. She was actually here, in person, right in front of him, her closeness overwhelming. Moira exhaled briskly, and bounced on her feet in anticipation, unsure what it should be. Looking to him to lead.

“Ah,” said Marshall, blinking. “I already have a table on the veranda.  I hope that’s agreeable?”

“Agreeable…” she repeated, as if testing the word, eyeing him thoughtfully. “Sure.”

Gesturing towards their table, Marshall followed her out. The room seemed to exhale around them, the din of conversation and movement of life resuming as she passed, seeping back into his peripheral vision. His sole focus was her, transfixed by the motion of her back as she walked, the sway of fabric and hair and hip, the flexing of her calves as the points of her stilettos plunged into the worn carpet. Her step was the lilting fall of a gazelle, steady and light. They found the table, and he smiled broadly as he helped her into the stool, mouth twitching to say something completely stupid without his warrant.

He scooped up his phone, set it to vibrate, and tucked it in an inside pocket before seating himself. Moira tracked every movement he made, unblinking, golden eyes like spotlights, brazenly studying every inch of him. Like a cat focused on its prey. Lucid, direct. Hot.

“I have to admit…” he began, damning the stupid grin his mouth had decided would now be its default state, “I’m struggling for words.”

“Oh? Why?” she asked, setting her clutch on the table, its posh satin like liquid in the sunlight. “Am I late or something?” A knowing smile played on her lips. 

“No, you’re not late at all,” he said, feeling like his chair was spinning beneath him. Images of those lips in lurid action swarmed his thoughts. If he didn’t clear those images, he’d put them to words. “You’re early. And thank you, by the way.”

“Of course.” She tilted her head to and fro as she talked. Impossibly adorable, with more than an undercurrent of attitude.

“I’m somewhat… taken aback,” he continued. “Pics on a screen often fail to convey the substance of a thing.”

“I know exactly what you mean.”

“Then you’ll pardon me if I’m anxious.”

Moira appraised him speculatively. “You don’t seem like the nervous type.”

“Not nervous. Eager.”

She made a small noise and repositioned her clutch on the table, from one empty spot to another. Catching herself fidgeting, she turned an abashed cheek, flushed in subtle rose. The afternoon sun greeted her face, silky skin aglow in the light.

Marshall gestured at the wine list. “Something to drink, or are you hungry?”

She drew a deep breath, eyes flashing emphatically.

“Definitely a drink.”

He twisted in his seat and beckoned the server. A brunette in a tuxedo shirt and black skirt at a nearby table, she acknowledged him with a self-conscious smile while scratching an order on her notepad, trying to maintain focus on her table.

Resettling in his chair, he slid his tie between his fingers and shrugged his blazer back into place. Marshall grinned at her.

“Our server should be round straight away.”

Moira followed his movements closely, eyes drinking in every detail. If she was always this intense in her appreciation of her date, likely she put a lot of men off. 

“You have an accent,” she noted. “I can’t place it. England?”

“I’ve done a lot of traveling, it’s probably a mix.”

“Like a lingual cocktail…” she quipped.

“Too right.” He had no more control over his smile than a kid at a carnival.

She indicated their surroundings with her eyes. “You sat outside. I was wondering how you’d handle that. I guess this doesn’t qualify as a restaurant?”

“Close,” he lifted a shoulder diffidently. “Patios don’t bother me as much.”

“So you just don’t like being inside restaurants?”

He laced his fingers together and knuckled his lip. “No.”

“Oh.” She blinked. “Was that… out of bounds?”

“Yes,” he said gently.

Glancing at the ceiling, she cleared her curls from her eyes with a short toss of her head. “I’m… asking a lot of questions.”

Marshall tilted his head in agreement. “You’re asking a lot of questions.”

“Well!” she laughed apprehensively. “Is that a bad thing?”

Shaking his head slowly, he mouthed a silent No. “You’re curious, that’s understandable.”

“Aren’t you?”

“Very.” I want to get to know you intimately. Explore what’s under all that de la Renta. In exquisite detail.

Moira flinched as her phone buzzed in her clutch. “Sorry…” she grimaced, reaching in and silencing it with a quick tap. Snapping the clutch shut, she exhaled roughly.

“Whoo…” she proclaimed, combing a particularly defiant curl off her face with a finger. “So this is kinda hard. How do you normally start these things off?”

“Just like this,” he replied, waving his hand.

Moira snorted. “Awkwardly?”

“If that’s what needs to happen.” First meetings often stumbled out of the gates, sentences floundered, drinks spilled. But a natural high that no drug could hope to compete with. “You only meet for the first time once, I just try to enjoy it. Be present. In the now.”

“I like that…” she smiled pensively, glancing at his rum-and-coke. He desperately wanted to know what thoughts were playing in her mind. She turned her eyes up to his, and he forgot what he was even thinking.

“So,” she continued, “what should we talk about?”

Marshall paused, spying an imposing man in a stiff black suit marching briskly through the lobby, his clip out of sync with passersby. A step ahead of him, a striking woman with wispy blond hair in a sprout of crimped spikes set their pace. She barked something at the man as they strode out of view.

Piqued, he frowned thoughtfully, as though considering Moira’s question. He couldn’t find his groove, kept getting thrown off by her, or his surroundings. Best to jump in the fire.

“Let’s talk about us.”

“To the point,” she laughed. “Ok, sure. Like what?”

“Like what are you particularly excited about?”

“Everything.”

“Tch-tch,” he admonished, “speak clearly, Moira.”

Eyes flaring, she pursed her lips tight before answering. “How so, Marshall?”

“Be specific. What are you most looking forward to?”

She shrugged, tilting her head self-consciously, but didn’t answer.

“Use small words,” he directed. “Brevity is the soul of wit.”

“Ok, Mister Bard,” she replied with a wry smile, and cleared her throat softly before continuing. “I’m really looking— well, curious about… spanking.”

“What about it?”

“I don’t know,” she shrugged again. “Just… curious.”

“Whether it’ll hurt?”

“Sure…”

“And if you enjoy it, does that say something about you?”

Pursing her lips, she ran her thumb along one of the seams on her clutch, and peered at him with golden eyes.

“Your first scene will surprise and confuse you,” said Marshall. “You can ponder it cerebrally, but it’s bigger than can be described with words. Kind of like a photo of a painting; just a facsimile, doesn’t prepare you for standing in front of an actual Van Gogh, seeing its brush strokes in person. You’re still overwhelmed by the real thing. Expect to struggle with that reality. How much it hurts, how much it doesn’t…” He captured her with a wolfish stare, “…and how much you enjoy it.”

Eyes burning hot, Moira swallowed an abashed smile as the server arrived to take her order. She recovered and dove headlong into the wine list, pointing at selections with piquant interest. Marshall settled back in his chair and grinned.

Past the bar entrance in the main lobby, the man in the black suit reappeared, turning on his heel as the woman with the crimped hair caught him up. She had a sharp-boned face and wide mouth, eyes obscured behind fashionably large sunglasses. Lavender mohair bolero sweater, a peek of muscular tummy dipping into the waistband of tight black leather leggings cinched with fat-buckled belts. Strappy skyscraper Loboutins, some wear showing at the toe. She stabbed into a handbag with dagger-point nails, lacquered in bubblegum purple, and snitted at the man. Alarm bells blared in Marshall’s ears.

Holy shit, it was Anka.

Scratching Moira’s order on her pad, the server turned her attention to Marshall. Still recovering from the shock, he waved her off politely, and tried to refocus. Moira startled as her phone buzzed insistently in her clutch once again. She snatched it out to quiet it, then paused at whatever was on the screen.

“Ugh!” she scowled. “I’m sorry… do you mind if I just take a moment?”

Tilting his head patiently, Marshall gestured his assent. Normally the interruption would nettle him, but his mind was already calculating likely scenarios for Anka’s appearance. And who was she with?

He glanced past Moira hammering out a message with her thumbs, and studied Anka’s companion. Stiff black suit, turtleneck, dark sunglasses. Polynesian perhaps, with a military buzz cut, and broad as a plow. The glasses blocked his eyes. Shoulders square, feet firm. Watchful, coiled.

Frustrated, Anka turned and stormed off the way they had come, the man hot on her heels. Marshall bit down the urge to shadow them. Fuming and distracted, he took a sip of his drink, immediately remonstrating himself for poor form; Moira didn’t have one yet.

What the hell was Anka doing in Portland? Of all the places in the world? And today, of all days? Cristoval must have sent her, the old fox. But how the hell could he know where Marshall was? He wouldn’t even know his current name. The buzzcut man posed a further mystery. The angle of his left arm suggested a weapon tucked into a holster beneath his jacket; Orgeon was open-carry, was he licensed to conceal? Or was he Fed? Had they inveigled her to track him down? No. She would never sell him out, but— He needed to get Jay on the phone ASAP.

“Sorry about that,” said Moira, stuffing her phone back in her clutch, nose wrinkling with an adorable, disarming grin. “Stupid work.”

Gaze pivoting to her, he reigned in his whirlwind of thoughts and waved off the apology. “Of course.”

“I meant to say, by the way,” added Moira, “love the suit.”

“Thank you,” he said simply, pulling his cuff into place over his watch. Dammit, she’d complimented him first. He needed to focus. “Cifonelli,” he continued, “I have a connection at the Paris store who was able to rush it for me.”

“The tailor is a genius,” she offered, as much with her eyes as her words. “Do you go there often?”

“Only for special occasions,” he said pointedly.

Moira hummed, the quirk in the corner of her mouth twitching, drawing him into her velvet lipstick. “So… this is a special occasion?”

“Very much, yes. This is a first for me.”

She gave him a curiously skeptical look. “What is?”

“Meeting you.”

Her teeth flashed in the sunlight as she laughed. She traced a seam on her clutch with a bronze fingernail. “That was very smooth, Casanova.”

Marshall crooked an eyebrow. “I mean it. I don’t give false compliments, remember?”

“Is that a count, then?” she said, cocking her Nordic chin in playful defiance. 

Marshall leaned on the table and fixed her with a pointed stare. “You walked in at 2:47, Moira. Did you notice the room stop for you? All the customers who turned and looked; men and women? And I did, too. I knew it was going to happen, I could tell from our chats. But I was totally unprepared for the real you… and I’m always prepared.

“Obviously this was not a chance meeting, but neither was us finding each other in the first place. Every second of our lives has brought us here,” he tapped the table with an index finger. “Every decision, every action we’ve ever taken—”

“Determinism,” Moira offered. “You’ve read Hume.”

“An unending chain of cause and effect,” he confirmed, enamored with her sharp mind. “One after another, over the course of each of our lives —and if I’m being really philosophical, all the way back to the beginning of time. What matters, though, is that it all led right here. To this moment. And here we are. So yes, I would call this a special occasion.”

Moira stared at him, her smile turned serious. “Life moment,” she murmured.

“Life moment. I like that.” He sat up straight again, unable to contain a wolfish grin. “And by the way, your count is now six.”

A rosy flush warmed her cheeks, as the corners of her mouth turned up in a smile, eyes sparkling like lanterns beneath the spray of her long, black lashes. She spluttered a laugh and flung her curls out of her eyes with a toss of her head. Everything about her was intoxicating.

The recognition of somebody approaching in his peripheral vision pulled his attention from her. It wasn’t the waitress.

Leaving her goon standing at the hotel entrance looking annoyed, Anka was making a beeline to their table, nearly six feet of Russian blonde and leather cutting through the crowd like a steam train. Marshall exchanged a glance with Moira, who’d also noticed the woman’s approach. The laughter from just a moment ago still painted her face, but he watched the realization of Anka’s advance lacquer her expression.

Dammit.

“Excuse me a moment,” he said, with a polite nod.

Moira didn’t turn her face from the intruder, only her eyes swiveled to meet him. Her smile wilted.

“It’s not like that,” he assured her. “A former colleague, I’ll explain—”

“Privet, krasavchik!” exclaimed Anka, closing on the table with a broad smile. “It is you! I don’t believe I find you here!”

With a last, hopefully reassuring look at Moira, Marshall stood and welcomed the newcomer with a platonic hug and peck.

“Privet, krasavitsa. Color me surprised.”

Anka took his face in her hands, beaming at him. “You look very handsome, I am happy to see you!”

Fifteen years away from Mother Russia had done little to soften Anka’s exaggerated accent, nor he saw, as she pulled off her sunglasses, the lurid scarring. Her smile carried to her brilliant blue eyes, even the right one, a prosthetic which she’d intentionally designed with a disconcertingly small pupil. Behind him, Moira swallowed a faint gasp.

“Good to see you again, as well,” he said, though a stabbing unease colored the thrill. “What brings you to Portland?”
title: 02 Special Occasion

content:
three

04.12 02:58 PM

Portland

Dickhead

Anka laughed, loud and nasal.

“I am not here for you, krasavchik, do not worry. I am visiting my brother, he is having baby.”

“Ah,” said Marshall, watched with interest as she stuffed her glasses into her purse. Anka didn’t normally busy herself during conversation. “Congratulations to him.”

“And who is this?” she continued, smiling down at Moira.

Moira rested her chin in her palm, openly simmering, curls playing in the breeze. Holy shit, she burned hot. Marshall stepped behind her and placed a hand on her shoulder. Her muscles tensed, but his fingertips thrilled at the touch nonetheless, the sleek fabric surprisingly warm in his palm, a thin sheet of copper between their skin.

“This is my date, Moira Berthelsen. Moira, this is Anyechka Mikhailovna. Anka.”

“Charmed,” said Moira, flaring her eyelids.

Surprised, the tall Russian stared down at her for a moment, then laughed and offered her fingertips. “It is nice meeting you, krasavitsa. I will not be long, I promise.”

Shrugging off Marshall’s palm, Moira stood to greet her. Her fingers were delicate in comparison to Anka’s, but the air between them vibrated with a tectonic rumbling. Marshall groaned inwardly.

“Who’s the mall cop?” he asked, nodding at the escort standing like a Centurion in the entrance, scowling at the passing crowd.

“Oh,” said Anka, with a dismissive wave over her shoulder, “that’s my Dickhead.”

The harumphing woman spluttered an ice cube into her glass. Her husband frowned at Anka, trying to look offended, but failing with flying colors. She evoked that kind of response often, a confusion of alarm and arousal. Marshall gave him a hard look, and the man glanced away to offer his wife a napkin. Irked, he turned to Anka with a grim eye.

“Anka...”

“Oh. Da.” She smirked. “Americans.”

“Indeed. Forgive me, it is very nice to see you… here in Portland,” he added pointedly, “but I must keep it short.”

“Of course, vozlyublennaya. We should talk soon, da? I have something you will not believe.”

That was curious news, the topic of which could go in a number of different directions. But now was clearly not the time to delve into it. “How long will you be here?” he asked.

“One week only. Then to Los Angeles.”

“Your brother is in LA? He left Russia?”

“Obviously.” Both eyes fixed on him. “Or I could not visit him, no?”

Marshall tilted his head apologetically. Touchy subject.

“Do not worry, milaya,” she said, smirking. “I know what you meant.”

She paused, swallowing the thought poised on her lips. Marshall knew. Four thousand miles and three years had come between them. She was angry and hurt. She’d forgive him everything, and they’d pick up right where they left, but she needed his explanation first. Clearly now was not the time, and neither she nor Marshall could decide whether they were grateful or vexed. Like him, she was here for a reason, and it wasn’t this.

“I must go,” she pronounced, turning a smiling eye at Moira. “I am sorry for interrupting date, Miss Berthelsen. Watch this one, he is big bad wolf. But good.”

Moira blinked, but before she could reply Anka turned and gave Marshall a quick peck on the cheek. “462,” she whispered, then stalked off, waving over her shoulder, long legs scissoring. She slapped Dickhead’s shoulder roughly, and without breaking stride, marched into the crowded lobby with him at her heel.

The gawping man at the next table called for his check, signaling other spectators to resume their conversation as well. Grumbling under his breath, Marshall returned to his chair, but paused an inch off his seat, disarmed by Moira’s searing leopard stare.

“My apologies,” he said, coughing discreetly as he settled.

“It’s fine.” She squared her shoulders and folded her arms on the table. “Just an old colleague, right?”

“Yes, and I’m as surprised as you are—”

“I’m not so sure about that.” Fire dripped from her smile.

“I understand,” he acknowledged. “I assure you that kind of thing does not happen—”

“Good. It’s rather awkward, isn’t it?”

Marshall regarded her intently, as amused by her sexy flame as he was piqued by her interruptions. Somehow he’d missed the diamonds glittering in her ears, but considering her entrance, that wasn’t too surprising.

“Yes, it is awkward,” he agreed. He grabbed the carafe and poured a glass of ice water, jaw twitching at the squeaky wet tinkle of the cubes against the glass. A restaurant sound. Returning the carafe, he slid the water over to her. “I assume you have questions.”

Moira barely glanced at the glass. “What did she whisper?”

Marshall blinked. There was no way Moira could have heard. She must have gleaned somehow, perhaps from Anka’s body language, or his. Impressed, he bit back an inappropriate smile. “She said ‘call me,’” he answered patiently.

“And you’re going to?” she demanded, gaze unflinching.

King of the Mountain

Sweat gleamed on his forearms and poured down the valley of his chest, his muscles contracting with each impact. It dripped from the tip of his nose, his nostrils flaring to pull as much air as possible. Marshall savored every salty drop, and ignored his clinging flannel.

He clambered down the mountainside, gripping the handlebars harder in his slick palms, feet steady on the spiked pedals. Hardtail mountain bikes could be ass-punishing, but the low-pressure 6Fattie tires soaked up all but the roughest landings, and churned the soil like saw blades. He grinned despite his complaining ankles, blood racing, hungry for speed.

The distant chopping of a helicopter piqued his hearing. Watching the sky, he pedaled through the trees, seeking a break in the canopy far above. Morning sunbeams pierced through, spotlighting clusters of brilliant yellow-green death caps nestled against fallen trunks.

Guided by the Doppler shift of the blades, he pedaled over to a ridge for a better viewpoint. His rear tire scraggled a smooth outcropping of sun-baked rock. He lifted off, clearing the lip and slamming down into a slippery carpet of moss. Power-stroking hard as he fought to stay upright, he caught traction and barreled back onto the path, and followed is to the spine of the ridge. From this vantage point, he could see the path ribboning down the mountain into the mists blanketing the Siskiyou Valley. Beyond the valley floor, another peak rose to a distant summit of jagged blades cutting into a periwinkle sky.

As he watched, the chopper rose from behind the peak like a raptor, gray and bleak with black windows. It pivoted, as if nosing his scent, a rotary camera on its belly aiming right at him. He could have sworn he heard the whine of actuators. Zeroing on his location.

He sped across the rough ground, plowing through a battalion of springtime raffia, its papery blades thrashing his shins. He dropped low to center his gravity, hit the knuckle like a ski jump, and lifted off.

He soared. Into open air, riding the breeze. Over spearheads of fir and pine —realizing with a rush of dread that he was way the shit too high. And exposed. Too late now. All he could do was remain vertical and hope he’d come down beneath the canopy, and as parallel as possible. Gravity beckoned.

Still airborne, he slammed into a wall of conifer, the world suddenly a slashing blur of green and brown. Branches tore at his sleeves, a thousand needles sliced every available inch of flesh. Bursting free of the stand, he slammed back onto the trail. The impact jarred every bone in his skeleton, rattling his teeth. He leaned into the bucking handlebars, righting his balance, and streaked down the path. Smooth as butter.

How the hell he’d done it he’d never know, but it didn’t matter. He was giddy to be breathing, never mind still on two wheels. All he heard was the rush of wind; the sky had gone silent. No helicopter. He whooped in victory, the King of the Mountain.

Still, he didn’t look back. He wanted more distance. Adrenaline flooding his veins, he clenched the handlebars in an iron grip. Veered left. Ducked under a low branch. Hopped a rain channel. Rounding a serpentine bend, he kicked the back tire into a controlled slide, and drifted gracefully past a towering raspberry bush.

Right into a felled tree.

Marshall floated momentarily in a peaceful stasis, afloat like a hummingbird. A second later, he hurtled bodily into the unforgiving ground. Cannonballing through an onslaught of raspberry thorns, wicked branches scratching and ripping at him as he plummeted through, he finally skidded to a halt amid a shower of dirt and scree.

Laying on his back, wheezing, he stared up at the serenity of an emerald canopy. The forest had gone deathly still, as if shocked by what it had just witnessed, save for a free-spirited wind shearing the treetops of the ridge somewhere far up the mountain.

He was alive. Probably. His howling skull raised some dispute.

Fairy lights twirled and sparked at the edges of his blurry vision. Groaning, he rolled onto his face, aware of nothing but the musty fragrance of virgin Oregonian earth. He lifted himself to knees and elbows, vaguely registering a taut resistance in his right leg. Taking a long minute to regain his breath, he purposed it to invoke every swear word he commanded. The mountain deigned neither to reply nor apologize. He sat back on his haunches, and blinked as his vision cleared.

In a sudden panic, he checked his father’s watch. Dusted and smeared, it ticked away steadily on his wrist. 8:02. Marshall exhaled in relief. He looked around groggily, gathering his surroundings, and spied the bike leaning upright against a cottony hemlock as though it were cheerfully waiting for him to finish crashing.

Lurching to his feet with a snarl, he teetered over to it, stomping as much from dizziness as fury. He snatched it up by the frame, and with a wild, spinning heave, flung it off the goddamn mountainside. Falling to a knee, he watched it sail over a battery of jagged stone, crashing into the ground somewhere beyond with a horrific racket of metal and rock. An introspective silence followed.

“Well… fuck,” he muttered, and sat down hard on the cool forest floor.

Very likely he had suffered at least a mild concussion. Standing up too soon expanded his list of stupid ideas so far this morning. If he weren’t more cautious, he could easily faint from hypotension. He settled himself, and ran a quick personal status check.

A hot, glowing pain blossomed in his leg. His cargos had been torn from knee to ankle, revealing a gouge running the length of his calf, strewn with dirt and twigs. Realization of the wound exacerbated it: the glow erupted into a furious blaze. Ripping the rest of his pant free, he wrapped it around and secured it with a tidy knot. A makeshift compression bandage to stanch the bleeding and swelling, if not the sting. He’d need that leg to get home.

The bike lay at the bottom of a rocky crag, bent and betrayed. Marshall stared at it for a moment, cursing himself, the bike, the forest, and the empty sky, too, just for good measure.

“Fine, I’m coming down there!” he called. Nature offered no response, save the nascent murmur of a breeze through tumbled, sunlit boughs of pine and alder.

Muttering and swearing under his breath, he slid and scraped his way down the gentler side of the crag to the bottom. The bike was fucked. No way he would leave it behind, though. That would be wrong. With a self-reproaching sigh, he pulled the safety releases on the tires, threw them over one shoulder, and hefted the frame over the other, annoyed at his own reaction.

Peering up the mountain, he could just make out a sliver of the white soffit at the far northwest corner of the house. He zeroed in on it for direction, and began climbing.

Thankfully, the mountain seemed to have contented itself that it had won, and threw no further challenges at him beyond the grade. He picked his way through lonely cliques of rock and the silent skeletons of the forest, amid fiddleheads of fern and Jack-in-the-pulpit. Though arduous, he enjoyed the climb, despite his throbbing shin. Two-thirds of the way up he paused for a rest, a chug of water, and to attend to his leg.

As he adjusted the bandage, a squirrel nattered at him from the safety of the canopy. Marshall watched it impassively, then laughed when it suddenly reminded him of Moira. Playful and amorous, a remarkable specimen of nature’s finest design work, and passionate about vocalizing displeasure. 

Mbeetle | 03/23 | 8:17 pm

User1138 | 03/23 | 8:18 pm

Nothing beats a summer campfire and a good whisky, or fresh powder in the Alps. Or Munro bagging.

And Carnevale. Or Mardi Gras. Or a weekend dancing in Beirut. ;)

And it’s like being inside a snowglobe where time stops, and nothing will happen, you’re safe and sheltered inside the dome. I loved it.

User1138 | 03/23 | 8:25 pm
