Mbeetle | 03/23 | 8:25 pm

Thank you. And it was. We should do that some time.

Marshall would enjoy bringing her out into the woods, watching her adapt to an agrarian environment. The dawning sun illuminating her curls, huddled into a thick flannel and sipping a steamy mug of weak coffee with both hands. High-stepping through swaying fauna and clawing underbrush in search of a secluded, creatureless place to pee. An energetic campfire painting her nose and cheeks in hues of gold.

Or tying her to a wispy alder and giving her a good cropping. Few things reconnected you to nature like nudity. Her breath steaming in puffs of exertion in the cold air, implacable tree bark etching her ivory Bel Air skin, the report of the crop echoing through the tranquil forest. Contrasts. Afterward he’d wrap her in a warm blanket, snuggled in his lap with a mug of hot cocoa, and read to her from Emerson or Thoreau.

Anka had enjoyed being read to. He smirked to himself, remembering the ending of Masha and the Bear. "Oni obnyali yeye i potselovali." They hugged her and kissed her.

What the hell was she doing in Oregon? Very likely his old friend and mentor Cristoval was involved, but why would he send Anka? If he wanted something done, he would’ve come himself. Was he ill? What in Portland would be of interest to him? He’d left three messages at the hotel, and no response. She wasn’t going to call him back, and the last thing he wanted to do was reach out to Cristoval for information. Once that box was re-opened…

The squirrel above barked a single note at him. Clearly not a fan of Russian folk tales, and Marshall had long overstayed his welcome. He gathered the dissembled bike back onto his shoulders and took to his feet.

Forty-three minutes later, he stepped out of the underbrush at his fence line, looking like something out of a rejected Jack London horror novel. Throughout the climb, the bike parts took a slow, maddening revenge on his outburst. An axle poked his ribs, the wheels ground into his hip, or trammeling like a half-ton ox yoke. He glanced at his watch as he pushed through the rickety gate on his way to the garage, ignoring the piercing screech of rusted iron hinges. 10:39. A short bike ride turned three hours.

“Stupid-ass,” he grumbled, latching the gate behind him. “Lucky you’re not lying in that crag with a broken back.”

Life bloomed into his aching shoulders as he relieved them of the bike. Fumbling with the frame, his articulation dampened by fatigue, the  metal-toothed pedal caught his shin, scraping into the gash on his leg and taking the bandage with it. Marshall leapt back, swearing, hot pain exploding into vengeance. He snatched the frame back up and lofted it into the air for the second time that morning, high over the gate and down the mountain. A moment later, both wheels followed, frisbee-style. Grumbling under his breath, he stomped off to the house to treat his leg and grab a cup of tea.

Stillness enveloped the house in a sleepy gauze, his footfalls echoing off empty walls as though he were walking on his own eardrums. He went directly to the control panel in the great room and flipped on his playlist. A Vivaldi violin concerto painted the silence, green and yellow, drifting through the air and his mind on motes of floaty springtime things. Exhaling, and leaning against the doorframe, a pang of guilt rose in his chest. The bike lay in some forlorn bush halfway down the mountain. What the hell was wrong with him? He’d go fetch it later, bring it back, and get it fixed.

He frowned at his reflection in the bay window. Just beyond, an old birdhouse stood crookedly in the southwest corner of the yard, solemn in the waning hours of the blue mountain morning. It hadn’t fostered a family in years, from what he could tell.

“I’m going to fix that damn thing,” he muttered, limping off to shower and tend his leg. “This is my damn house, and I’m going to go out —ow, dammit— and fix the hell out of that birdhouse.”

He wasn’t just a gust of wind passing through, and to hell with getting chased out. Not again. This was his home. Rather than wait for it to accept him, he would claim it.

04.18 11:02 AM

Agness

Ice Packs & 

Bedtime Stories

Sinking onto the creamy calfskin sofa in boxers and a t-shirt, Marshall leaned back and cautiously stretched himself over the cushions, positioning a medical-grade ice pack across his shin with a groan of relief.

Sparsely decorated, the room contained only the sofa and matching armchair, a tiered coffee table, and easels bearing the Vermeer and Leighton. Two large, unpacked crates stood before the bay windows, unwieldy, utilitarian monoliths containing busts of the Marquis de Sade’s infamous heroines, Justine and Juliette. Hedy would be returning to set these up to her liking (if not Marshall’s) as well as see to the Malm fireplaces. The white one would reside in the great room as he’d asked, the gray one in the dining room. She’d grumble about it at first, he knew, but then find some clever way to arrange them and still claim victory. And she’d be right, of course.

His leg cleaned and properly bandaged, he already felt fifty times better. Stitches were certainly in order, but the last thing he needed was to spend an afternoon dodging all the prying personal questions at an emergency room triage. Handing over a credit card instead of an insurance card, explaining that he’s self-employed. No, I dont’t have a social security card. No, I dont’t have a regular GP (even though he did, just in a nondescript home office in DC). Too many questions, screw that. The whole point of coming to Agness had been to stay under the radar.

Stormy Weather floated like feathers from recessed speakers in the ceiling, soothing his mind and affording him a long, deep breath. Keely and dreamy French jazz had provided most of the soundtrack for his time in Melun, France, where he first met Cristoval. They’d hit the Parisian club scene like a pair of cruise missiles, a mysterious American gentleman and a refined, silver-haired Spaniard. Two years of steamy nights filled with fine wine, supple women, and singing leather. So much laughter.

Anka, Cristoval, L’Abbazia… and his former Padrona. Mistress. After seven years and across four thousand miles, her beautiful, wicked eyes still commanded him. Black and penetrating and cruel and lustful. A bleak goddess, and she would be sure to remind him of it. Her coolness soothed his heat as no ice pack could, nor would any distance ever dull the craving, clinging like a heavy fog at his breastbone. No wonder he’d chosen to throw himself off a mountain.

Padrona was not his immediate concern, however. Anka was. She didn’t know it, and didn’t mean to be, but she was a threat. After all this time, he’d love nothing more than to bring her to Agness, put her up in the guest room and spend a month drinking wine and reminiscing. The thrill of seeing her in Portland had been eclipsed by the moment, but ever since, memories of L’Abbazia, the ancient Padovan monastery, ghosted his thoughts.

He and Anka had been very intimate, which was the real question Moira had been asking. In retrospect, he should have been more honest, and wished he had. Half-truth is not truth.

The truth was that she had been his best friend, with whom he’d laughed and teased and passed sunny days maintaining Cristoval’s family vineyard in Sottomonte, and that was to say nothing of the evenings. Cristoval called their little group of vagabond kinksters I Monaci Peccatori, The Sinner Monks. Marshall and Anka had joined their ranks together, forever kindred under the same banner. La fratellanza. Our Family. The only one he had.

His phone buzzed on the marble counter, rattling like an electric knife on a cinder block. Wincing, Marshall smacked it down. Christ, he was wired as fuck, and annoyed with himself for it. How could he have allowed things to get here? Expelling a harsh breath, he tapped the icon for speakerphone.

“This is Marshall.”

“Privet, krasavchik.”

“Privet, Anka.”

“So your name is Marshall now?” She gave a low, husky laugh.

“At the moment.”

She never could understand the point of anonymity; if they want you, they’ll find you, and being difficult about it only makes them find you angrily.

“I like it…” she said, letting the statement hang.

“But?”

She paused, huffing softly, as though she were walking up stairs. “…but always you are Il Lupo.”

“Maestro Lupo,” he corrected playfully, and leaned back on the arm of the sofa. Master Wolf. It sounded pretentious and pretend, but Cristoval had insisted that it fit him perfectly, and so it had stuck.

“Maestro…” Anka made a noise of amusement, probably tracing her jawline with a bold-colored fingernail, as she often did in moments of thoughtfulness. Even through the thin phone speakers, her voice was a somatic experience, pooling in his ears and melting through him like a shot of Tsarskaya vodka. A slow, heavy heat. “That was fun night.”

“Very much so. You put on a hell of a show—”

“As did you, vozlyubennaya.”

“Thank you, but the highlight of that evening was you,” insisted Marshall. “I’ve never seen its like, and I’ve never seen anybody wear white Versace the way you did.”

Anka scoffed harshly. “I know your tricks, Lupo, and sexy voice. You are pulling Dom on me.”

“I would never pull Dom on you, and I don’t give—”

“—false compliments,” finished Anka. “I know.”

“Then you should know I mean it,” he said, working a pillow under his leg with a bare foot. Anka had always been an impatient conversationalist, terse and constantly interrupting. A personal pet peeve of his, but not with Anka, though he had no idea why. “Anyway,” he continued, “before I say anything else, how are you, milaya?”

“I am doing well.” 

A faint stretching sound piqued his ears, like vinyl being pulled taut. “What’s that noise in the background?”

“Crunches,” she said, with a grunt of exertion. “Inversion table. You have tried these?”

Marshall laughed softly. Anka was cut like a Siberian diamond, and nearly as hard, a sculptor whose favorite medium was her own physique. If she was awake, she was working out, usually on some new-fangled contraption she’d found. Anything that targeted a specific muscle group —or replicated some medieval torture— drew her like a bear to honey.

“No,” he chuckled. “I stick to old-fashioned workouts. Have you ever tried just exercise?”

“Do you use sundial for clock, Lupo? Nyet. Inversion table is good for old men, you should try.”

“I don’t think those were intended for play,” he quipped back.

“It is not for play,” she huffed again, “it is exercise.”

“Of course. Speaking of, how is Rodrigue?”

“Mudak!” she snarled, viciously enough that she paused in her crunches to devote her full power to her thoughts. The table clanged stolidly into place. “Yemu povezlo, chto ya ne zadushil yego tupuyu Frantsuzskuyu golovu!”

Marshall stifled a laugh. His Russian had never been very strong, but it was abundantly clear she wasn’t happy with Rodrigue at the moment, and would not likely share his humor.

She had been Rodrigue Charpentier’s Domme for more than ten years, but would never admit aloud that she loved him. Their relationship was nothing if not embattled, generally due to him pulling some irredeemable stunt like bringing her flowers, which Anka would threaten to use as a murder weapon. She could be very creative in her application of mundane objects for violence.

“You’re going to… choke his French head?” he asked.

She grunted in disgust. “Do not talk to me about him.”

“Yes, Mistress.” Marshall grinned. “I understand—”

“I am not Mistress. Have you talked to her?”

He swallowed his smile. “No.”

“Ask me how is she,” said Anka imperiously.

Marshall pinched the bridge of his nose and sighed. There was no way he’d get through this conversation without her coming up, and even though he’d expected it, it still pinged.

“How is she?”

“She is missing you, Lupo,” answered Anka, an earnest plea in her voice. The note hung heavy in his ears. “We all are. You should come home.”

Marshall sighed again, adjusting his foot on the pillow. “Anka, this is my home—”

“I miss you,” she blurted. “Voglio andare a letto con te.”

I want to sleep with you.

An inside joke from Italy, instantly transporting him to the mysterious old villa in Sottomonte. Casa della Fine Viaggio. Thick stucco walls and plank floors, scuffed and scarred by four centuries of householders. Gauzy curtains furled in every iron-latticed window, kissed by the breeze off the Gulf of Trieste. The scents of honeysuckle, grape vines and cappuccino. His room had been hardly more than a closet, but he’d been more at home there than anywhere he’d ever lived, before or since.

He lay on his cot in a sheen of sweat on a muggy July night, dappled in gossamer moonlight. The day had been scorching, and the advent of evening merely lowered the heat to a dim boil. Thin sheets kicked half aside so the wind might whisper across his bare skin, he would have given a minor appendage for a respite from the sweltering air, especially the hot sting of the brand on his shoulder blade.

Padrona’s perfume wafted faintly off the thick leather slave collar circling his throat. She’d formally presented it to him a month before, the drunken buzz of their romance still young and vibrant. He was a Dominant, a Master, and his contentment as her slave was a mystery he couldn’t solve.

Pondering his collar and his bleak, seductive goddess, a single, crisp rap at the iron-bound door cracked the sleepy silence of the villa. He nearly leapt off the cot to kneel on the rough wood planks. But it wasn’t his goddess who slipped quietly over the threshold. Instead, one of the other I Monaci Peccatori Dommes tucked inside the door and leaned against it.

He was used to seeing Anka in various states of undress, as part and parcel with life at the vineyard, but her tall, athletic figure glowed especially pale and beautiful that night. She’d drawn her hair up into a tight blonde bun, not a single strand awry. A diaphanous cami hung off her carved shoulders, the penetrating moonbeams leaving very little to the imagination. Plain cotton panties hugged her close, drawn tight across her pelvis and hips, an eye-popping triangular swell between her thighs.

Che diavolo, why the hell was she in his room? Dressed like that? Barely dressed like that? His mind reeled with the possibilities, each one as sensual and complicated as the next.

“Sei sveglio, Lupo?” she asked softly, in her endearing broken Italian. Are you awake?

She stepped in on the balls of her bare feet, a clear hesitancy in her gait.

“Se non lo ero prima,” he replied, rising to his elbows, “lo sono adesso.” If I wasn’t before, I am now.

“Voglio andare a letto con te.” She lifted her head, staring down hard at him. Commanding.

I want to sleep with you.

He raised an eyebrow. Their friendship had always run flirtatious, but unassuming and easy. She’d never made a play for him, and besides, they were both typically Dominants. Did she think he would suddenly sub for her now because of the collar? Holy shit, if Padrona found out— or…

“Sei stato mandato da Padrona?” he asked. Did Mistress send you? If she had, he’d have no choice. He’d have to submit.

“Pridurok,” scoffed Anka, switching to Russian, “ya ne eto imel v vidu.”

With his muddled brain, he couldn’t make out if she’d called him a moron or an asshole. Shaking his head in confusion, he rubbed his eyes to assure there was no sleep in them.

“Anka, it’s late, can we pick a language? What is it, vozlyubennaya?”

A beat. “My fucking sister had baby,” she said perfunctorily. “It’s a girl.” She jammed her fists against her hips, clamping her wide lips tight. Clearly that explained everything.

“That’s wonderful,” he offered. She stared at him impassively. “Congratulations, Auntie Anka?”

“I am not wonderful.”

Pressing his lips together thoughtfully, he nodded. “All right. Care to explain?”

“I am two thousand miles away, chert poberi.” Devil take it, a colloquialism that roughly meant dammit. She turned to the window, lacing her fingers together in front of herself and letting them fall against her belly. Melancholy traced her usual dour scowl, and for all her pristine, imposing stature, she looked brittle.

“I do not know,” she said, shrugging feebly. “I will not have baby… and I miss Nizhny Tagil.” She rarely spoke of her home, a decrepit, repressed mining town in Siberia. She drew next to the bed and nudged one of his knees with her own.

“Move over, Lupo.”

Standing over him like a Russian goddess in holy light, it seemed like the worst idea in the world. The cot barely held him alone, where would she fit? Still, he couldn’t tell her no. He’d just have to control himself. And her.

Without replying, he scooched a scant inch, attempting to chastely tuck the sheet beneath him just as she yanked it aside.

“I wouldn’t…” he began, but too late. Anka glanced briefly at his naked cock, smirked, and climbed in, facing him.

She slapped his hand away as he tried to cover them. “It is too hot for blanket, you will boil me. Lay on your back.”

“On my back?” Another terrible idea, and not the last—

Shoving him by his shoulder, she threw an arm across his broad chest and a leg over his thigh. He acquiesced, in spite of her display of Dominance, the extra movement and weight flaring the burning emblem on his shoulder blade. Settled like a kitten on a pillow, Anka sighed contentedly. 

Fresh lemongrass soap wafted off her smooth skin, and he couldn’t help but notice that she felt incredible. Strong and lithe, but also unusually vulnerable. He slipped an arm around her shoulders, pulling her tight against him despite the oppressive heat. Searching for safe thoughts not involving Anka, he lay silent, keenly aware of each drop of sweat on their bodies.

Art…

Padrona had loved La Galleria Borghese in Roma. She’d spent an hour staring at Bernini’s sculpture of Proserpina, her face a mirror of the smooth, hard marble. Her fingers twitched with yearning, dark eyes roving over the sensuous liquidity of the stone, the implied strength of Pluto’s demanding fingers sinking suggestively into Proserpina’s supple thigh…

Damn.

Anka shifted for comfort, underscoring the compression of her breast against his ribs, and the sultry heat generated anywhere their skin contacted. Some places more than others. The sauna that was his room had turned into an oven, fueled by her presence.

“Do you have family at home?” she asked, her voice soft and raspy.

“No.”

A short silence. “So you don’t miss home?”

“Very much,” he said, rubbing her shoulder gently. Now he understood. Births in a family had a way of underscoring the passage of time, and the true distance of miles. “You know…  your sister is thinking about you, too, Anka.”

“Da.” Shifting again, she slid her leg higher on his thigh, leaving a patch of brief coolness in her wake. He was torn between wanting her to keep going, or grabbing her leg to hold it in place. “I wonder what she is thinking.”

“She misses you,” he said, leaning his cheek against the top of her head. “She wishes you could meet your niece.”

“That is the problem. I cannot go back. You know this.”

“Think of it another way, milaya,” he told her, his voice low and rumbling. “Do you want your sister to be happy?”

“Of course, don’t be stupid.”

“She wants you to be happy, too. She wouldn’t want you to be sad about the baby—”

“I am not sad about baby,” she said curtly. He could hear her scowl.

“You think you should be there for her?”

“I should not have left at all.”

“That wasn’t up to you, was it?” Sliding his hand down to her ribs, he squeezed her reassuringly. “You have new choices now, Anka. Be happy, whatever that means for you. Decide what that is, and do that.”

Anka grunted dismissively. “And what if I decide to go home anyway?”

“Would that make you happy?” he asked, knowing the answer. She didn’t reply.

The night was far too hot, and the moon too bright. If he entertained this train of thought with her, she would wallow. Better that she put her troubles to rest for now. Her mood would ease with daylight.

“Go to sleep, orsetto,” he said gently. Little bear, a term of endearment assigned her by Cristoval. “I got you.”

She made a noise of assent. He lay with her body in his grip, absentmindedly admiring her form with his fingertips. Anka was a work of art, as hard and smooth as Proserpina, and just as deliberately carved. He shifted his hand safely back to her shoulder.

“Maegen says you are… il cattivo lupo,” said Anka softly.

“Il lupo cattivo,” he corrected. The big, bad wolf. Where did that come from?

“You are big bad puppy,” she chuckled.

He laughed as well, half at himself, laying there in his collar. He gave her a forbearing smile. “Mio dolce amico… go to sleep.”

“I am not sweet,” she muttered thickly.

She shifted closer, clearly meaning to suffocate him or set him aflame, especially as her thigh ground against his disquieted cock. Clearing his throat, he stared at the ceiling, willing himself to calm.

Long minutes passed, the seconds tip-tapping across his beaded forehead. Her breathing grew easy, and after an eternity, she relaxed in his arms. He lay in desirous torture, as she drowsed in peaceful dishabille.

Despite himself, he felt an impulse to squeeze her thigh, and stupidly, glanced down, over the flat planes of his belly at her sprawled across him. He allowed himself to stare, his cock awakening to his imagination, stiffly seeking its source.

Two radiant blue eyes stared back at him, perfectly matched in a perfect face, as brilliant as if they were lit from within. She smiled, sapphire irises aglow, her expression an intriguing mix of confidence and guile and playfulness.

Without warning, she rolled on top of him.

“Anka—” he protested, but she covered his mouth imperiously with a salty palm. Her firm thighs tightened against his sides, and she plopped herself down on his erection with aplomb. She was an inferno beneath the thin cotton of her panties, searing a bas relief of her contours onto his shaft.

“Just one time,” she said, the words pouring like liquor from her lips, muddling his conscience. “Because friends, da?”

He blinked at her, but didn’t reply. She hovered over him, droplets of sweat on her angled face sparkling in the moonlight. Instinctively, he grabbed her thighs, and she tautened in his grip, sleek and firm, and tantalizingly powerful.

Tugging his lower lip with a fingertip, she pulled her hand away and rose up onto her knees. Crossing her arms, she took the hem of her cami, and tugged it over her head. Her breasts were as taut as the rest of her, gentle mounds capped with pale areola, and soft, pudgy nipples. She plopped the cami over his eyes, and as he pulled it off, leaned forward and dragged a breast across his lips.

Dropping the cami to the side of the cot, he stretched all the way to his toes. How the hell could any man be expected to resist when Anyechka Mikhailovna Chekova wanted something? Especially him?

She flexed her legs, pressing her bottom firmly against the top of his thighs.

“Anka…” he growled, taking her by the waist and squeezing hard.

Ignoring his remonstration, her mouth parted as she dropped her gaze to her own roaming hands, tracing the striations of his damp chest, his skin lighting to her touch. Her skillful fingers glided over his ribs and along the ridges of his abdomen. He drew a breath, stomach tightening as her nails etched his shapes. Breathing heavily, she caressed between her legs, cupping herself in her palm, the tendons between her open thighs and groin pulled taut. She loosed a husky groan, a shudder rippling through her and vibrating directly into him. Reaching down further, she took hold of his rigid staff, and with her other hand, pulled her panties to one side.

Her vulva bloomed like wedges of grapefruit, flushed pink and dewy. He kissed her forehead and squeezed her waist. “Go to sleep,” he grumbled back, the words thick in his throat.

The following morning, he put her in the car and drove her into Trieste, where they spent the day picking out blankets and baby clothes, hand-carved wooden toys and rattles, a million stuffed animals, and shipped them to Nizhny Tagil.

Their evenings changed after that. Anka would often slip in beside him to cuddle, a comfortable intimacy with no demands or expectations. No matter their states of (un)dress, they were friends, albeit inexorably drawn together like two powerful magnets whose poles resisted contact. After a few more sexually-charged close calls, Marshall took up reading to her until she fell asleep. Russian classics, Tolstoy and Nabukov, and Italian romance paperbacks, but Anka loved fairy tales the most. He’d read Masha and the Bear so often he could recite it in its entirety, in English and Russian, despite having only a rudimentary knowledge of the language.

Surprisingly, Padrona never said a word about their soirees, nor would she allow him to.

The ice pack slipped on his throbbing leg, dispersing the languorous fog from his head. He shifted his weight on the sofa to ease the pressure. An ardent noon sun poured mote-specked rays through the bay windows, washing Juliette’s crate in picturesque brilliance.

“Lupo!” Anka barked, her commanding voice punching through the phone. “You are daydreaming.”

“Yeah, sorry. Old memories,” he muttered, returning to reality. Voglio andare a letto con te. Dammit, she was not making this easy. “So what’s the story with the rent-a-cop?”

“Dickhead?” Slamming her refrigerator closed, she scoffed loudly. “He is business acquaintance, I told you this. You are changing subject.”

“Yes, I am,” said Marshall curtly. “Anka, I’m not going back to Sottomonte. My door is always open for you if you need somewhere to go—”

“Fuck that,” she snapped, then gulped a few quick swallows of something. “If you will not come home, fine, but don’t expect me to come crawling to you.”

Marshall growled under his breath. Iron-headed woman. “Care to tell me why you’re really in Portland?”

“L’Abbazia business. Stop asking me.”

“Business. Like Cristoval is looking to host an Event here?”

“Da.”

“Why Portland?”

“Portland is kink capital of America, Lupo,” said Anka, curiously. “You do not know this?”

“No.”

Portland made perfect sense, if a bit convenient. Would Cristoval be sending the rest of the Monks? Gattina, Maegen and the others? Padrona? That entire crew in the States would bring nothing but complications. He’d have to hole up in a bunker in the middle of nowhere to keep them out of his hair.

Anka barked sharply. “Please, Lupo. If you did not know, why are you in Portland?”

Marshall sat up straight, easing his leg off the sofa with a labored grunt, its numbness giving over to pain. He’d hoped to take her off balance with a quick change of subject, to maybe pick up on a tell that she wasn’t being completely forthcoming, but as far as he could discern, she was telling the truth.

“As I said, I move a lot. This is just where I happened to be.”

“Hmm,” she said, unconvinced.

“Mm,” he grunted back, low and laced with irony.

“You are giving me bedroom voice again. Stop that.”

Good thing for her she was a few hundred miles away, or he might give her more than just his bedroom voice. “Tell me the thing I would not believe.”

“Ah,” she said. A short cluffle ensued while she shifted the phone, then exhaled dramatically as she took a rest. “Cristoval has new pet. Luciana.”

The name rung a bell, dimly, gathering slow clarity like a reverse resonance. “Luciana?”

“Da. The bomb?”

“Luciana la bomba?” he asked, pitch rising.

“That’s what I said,” snarled Anka. “She joined last year.”

This was news. Luciana Salocchi was called The Bombshell for very good reason. Cristoval likened her to a young Ornella Muti, and he, along with every other man who laid eyes on her, would gladly fight an enraged bull with a plastic spoon for a chance at her. If Marshall was being honest, he might, too, and nevermind the spoon. Luciana was the kind of stunning that ignited wars.

“Really,” he said flatly.

“Do not play tricks, Lupo. You are popping from jeans right now.”

“I’m not wearing jeans.”

Anka laughed, her adorable snort an endearing contrast to the hard Domme. “I am not fool. You wanted that one.”

He ignored that. “So she joined the Monks? Good for Cristoval.”

“Da, but she is not good, Lupo. Very mean. She is hurting clients, and Cristoval cannot fix her.”

“And he wants me to,” said Marshall.

She paused, her ploy clearly missing its mark. Marshall wished he could console her. He’d return to Trieste in a heartbeat if it were up to him. It wasn’t. And what would he tell Moira? ‘Off to Sottomonte, mio amico, you should come visit some time.’ Her golden eyes would blaze like furnaces, with her wild hair and quirky scowl, her fury scorching everything within a fifty mile radius. The safety of San Francisco was in his hands.

“Anka, I am not fool, either. Is that why you’re here? Cristoval thinks he could entice me back to Trieste with Lucianna la Bomba?”

“Ask me again and I punch your stupid face off,” she said. “I am not here for you, and I am not talking about Cristoval. I am telling about la Bomba because she is needing help. Cristoval is old and blockhead, he makes her angry, so she only fights him. But you could help. You could show her correct ways, and I know you wanted to.”

“No.” Rubbing his face with his hands, he stood and paced the coffee table, favoring his aching shin. “Anka, you know as well as I do what will happen if I set foot in Italy again.”

“Your Padrona loves you. She would never—”

“That die has already been cast.”

“Pridurok. You are being difficult. Always difficult.”

Marshall chuckled weakly. “Pridurok. Is that moron or asshole?”

“It is Marshall.”

“Touché.”

“This is about woman at restaurant. Your date?”

“My client,” he scolded.

Anka gave a long, throaty laugh. “Lupo. I know you. I saw how you look at her, she is not client any more than La Regina Lydia—”

“That’ll do,” he interrupted, brooking no further discussion on that topic.

Marshall picked up his phone and limped into the great room to the bay windows. It was not himself he saw in the reflection, however, but Moira. As though she stood in front of him, her body perfectly proportioned to being wrapped in his. Her smile inviting. Her eyes defying. He had no doubt that she would rage if he left, though uncertain as to why. Abandonment? Money?

“You like this one,” said Anka, breaking the long silence.

“Mm,” he shrugged, ignoring a tug at his throat. 

Moira had breathtaking eyes, and if that weren’t enough to disarm him —and they were— her voice had a way of seeping right into his bones. Warming, heating. Melting. He scowled at his reflection. 

“She’s a new client,” he said, “new to the lifestyle, too. Hard to say where she’ll land this early in the game.”

“She will not decide this, Lupo, you will. She lands where you are pointing. Always they do for you.”

“Some. Not all.”

“All,” she insisted, with an air of finality. “Is ok, I will not badger you. I must go now.”

Had he not known Anka better, he’d have called that out as reverse psychology. That had never been her style. “Call Cristoval and tell him I’m not diffusing his bomb,” he said.

“And what do I say to Padrona?”

He paused. Dammit. “Tell her I hope she is well.”

“Difficult,” scoffed Anka. “You should call her.”

“Do svidaniya, krasavitsa.”

A beat. “Ciao, Lupo. Te amo.” She deliberately ended the call before he could reply.

Marshall tapped the phone against his fingertips.

Something he would not believe. Cristoval wouldn’t send Anka halfway across the world to lure him with a sexy sub, not even Lucianna la Bomba. Though the prospect of training her was definitely appealing, going back to Trieste would be walking into a minefield, and Cristoval knew it.

Anka may have been telling the truth, but she hadn’t told him everything. She thought he’d be interested in Luciana, yes, but that was only part of the story. For the rest of the story, he would have to unravel Dickhead. He was the key. Nothing about him fit in with the Sinners, he was the only variable unaccounted for.

He went to the kitchen and dropped the ice pack in the sink with a grating clatter. What the hell would Anka know about his relationship with Moira? Or relationships at all, for that matter? She could never commit to Rodrigue, and if what they had wasn’t love, there was no such thing. How he looked at Moira? She was a beautiful woman, how else should he look at her?

And what the hell had he come into the kitchen for?

Medford, OR

Mind Your Peas and O’s

Pacing the private charter lounge at Rogue Valley International Medford Airport, he sipped coffee from a paper cup, ignoring the muted news channel on the TV over the faux fireplace. Calling it coffee was generous; it was a nuclear, coffee-flavored drink that burned his fingertips if he held it one hand for too long. He wasn’t really tasting it anyway, his mind was elsewhere.

Moira was due in at 7:22; he’d been there since 6:41, watching the planes and losing himself in thoughts of her. His focus shifted from the tarmac to his reflection in the glass, and his growing laugh lines. He’d been putting them to use a good deal since seeing Moira. She liked to laugh, and to make him laugh.

As predicted, she charged into her D/s experience brain first. She was a deer in headlights initially, and had been awestruck by the intense, heady experience of her inaugural spanking. Sex had been raucous and lawless, and afterward she lay in the bed staring at the ceiling, panting and limp. The next morning, she was chatty and exhilarated, munching crisp melon, crunchy bagels, and a poached egg, while happily recounting and analyzing her favorite moments and activities. Unfortunately, she’d also spent much of the evening deconstructing his psychology as a Dominant.

What she lacked in experience, she made up for with assiduity. She had devoured a small library of books on BDSM before the session, and peppered Marshall with questions throughout the weekend. “Do people have random sex at clubs? Sounds dangerous, do they negotiate a contract each time? Where the hell do you buy a St. Andrew’s cross anyway? Dominant Depot?”

A lesser Dom would slap the Brat label on her, but they’d be wrong. An experienced brat wields misbehavior, deliberately pushing buttons to elicit a specific response from the Top. As a novice submissive, Moira wasn’t aware of this dynamic. Her disobedience wasn’t deliberate, it was her personality.

Marshall’s vision shifted to the observing window as an Alaskan Air 707 drifted to the runway and touched down with a squawk of its landing gear. He smoothed the lapel of his navy blazer, Saint Laurent two-button in wool gabardine, with a simple, white shirt. Slim cut to his physique, and refined, but the lack of a tie was perhaps too casual. He was not the type of man that only dressed up long enough to close the deal, and he hoped she wouldn’t misperceive. Moira liked cuff links, and despite a new pair glinting at his wrists, his eyes returned to the tie-less collar.

In the corner of the lounge, the coffee machine stirred to life with clicking thermocouplers and a surge of electricity-hungry coils. Four seconds later, the front panel flickered. Three more seconds, the fans kicked in with a bark. Sipping his Chernobyl coffee, he squinted one eye shut, grunting in disapproval. More fake creamer would only make it worse.

Beyond the window, a sleek, white Cessna Citation taxied into the lot with a whine of turbines. 7:21, that must be her. He dropped the pseudo-coffee in a trash can, blinking rapidly to clear the corn syrup aftertaste as he straightened his cuffs. Combing his forelock back with his fingers, he stepped outside to greet her.

The cabin door swung open and the pilot dropped the stairs to the tarmac. Moira waved brightly, dark curls wild and waving in a sunlit breeze, long skirt billowing as she descended the stairs. White peep-toes with three-inch heels peeked from her hem with each step. Conservative, but her pretty feet conjured images of slurping champagne off her toes. She wore black and white cotton toille, fit snugly to her bust and waist. Three men in business suits filed off the plane behind her carrying laptop bags and briefcases. Engaged in their own conversation, they didn’t appear to be traveling with her specifically, nor did she pause to say goodbye. She came straight to Marshall, eyes sparkling mirth.

Marshall counted eighteen small, metal snaps on the front seam, from her bustline to her knees. He flexed his fingers, anticipating the sequential, gratifying pop of each snap as he tugged the dress open.

“Hi!” she chirped, adjusting a travel purse on her shoulder.

“Moira.” He took her hand, grinning broadly. His face had made a habit of that lately. She swept into an easy hug, his hands delighting to caress her waist again. He kissed her cheek, the electric spark from their first date leaping to his lips. Her perfume washed over him, the same fragrance as before, leather and wood. She stepped back all too soon, beaming at him.

“You look sensational,” he said, drinking her in.

“Oh, this isn’t really anything.” She flung her hair off her face and glanced down at the dress. “It’s an off-brand, I don’t even—”

“Proper response to a compliment?”

Moira pursed her lips, repressing a smile. “Thank you.”

“You’re welcome.” Marshall leaned in and dropped his voice. “Love the snaps. Very promising.”

“Great minds think alike,” said Moira, pushing his hair off his forehead with a pleased hum. The two weeks between them dissolved, they were picking up right where they’d left off. Flirting as though no time had passed at all with sparking, effortless chemistry.

“You are so handsome Mr. Vaughn.” She traced his jaw with her fingertips, raising goosebumps the length of his arms. “Navy goes great with those sexy blue eyes. I am so looking forward—”

“Your bags, Miss Berthelsen?” called one of the pilots, pulling her luggage out of the cargo.

Her fingers left a trail of flame. “Thanks, Midas,” she called, without turning to look.

“I can’t wait either, Moira,” said Marshall, completing her previous line of thinking. 

She smiled at him thoughtfully, the gears in her mind clearly churning. The pilot arrived with her bags before she could put them to words.

“Marshall,” she offered, by way of introduction, “this is my pilot—”

“Andrew Feiderhoff,” the man said, bringing the luggage to a stand. Tall with dark wavy hair, his steel gray eyes added  sparkle to a charming smirk. Pilot shirt drawn tight across a heavily muscled chest, badged epaulets accentuating his massive shoulders to brow-raising effect. He walked elbows out, shoulders back, chin high, proud in his skin. Military; probably a hotshot fighter pilot who’d never grown out of attack birds. Or tanks, as he was practically built like one.

He thrust a genial hand at Marshall, bulging forearm bearing a tattoo of Felix the Cat with a lit bomb, Fighting 31 scrawled on a banner beneath. “Captain Feiderhoff, I should say, but friends call me Midas.”

Marshall shook his hand perfunctorily while Moira fished in her luggage, one watchful eye trained on the men. 

“Marshall Vaughn. Good to meet you.”

“So you’re the lucky dog,” said Andrew with a toothy grin, holding Marshall’s hand slightly longer than customary.

“That’s one way of putting it.” Just behind Andrew, Moira wrinkled her nose with distaste. Marshall nodded at the man’s tattoo. “Navy.”

“Thirty-first Tomcatters,” said Andrew, glancing at it himself. “USS Teddy Roosevelt, Operation Iraqi Freedom, oh-three.”

“Ah.” Marshall tilted his head respectfully. “Thank you for your service, soldier. Nice to know she’s in capable hands.”

“Well sir, she is a VIP.” Andrew shrugged humbly, his grin brightening, if that were even possible.

“I couldn’t agree more. As far as I’m concerned, she’s royalty.”

“Royalty, really?” said Moira, zipping her luggage shut and settling a wide-brimmed hat atop her head. She tied a bow beneath her chin, shifted her purse to the crook of her arm, and slipped her free hand inside Marshall’s elbow. “Guess I should have packed my tiara instead.”

Marshall winced internally. “Shall we, your highness?”

“Aw, that’s cute,” Andrew laughed. Moira gave him a confused sort of smile, but Marshall turned a cool eye on him. “A queen with her knight-in-shining armor, huh? That’s great!”

“You’re so sweet, Midas,” said Moira quickly, before Marshall could get a word in. Her pointed sidelong glance suggested he might like to concur. Not bloody likely. He didn’t care for Andrew’s delivery, or his face.

“Call ‘em as I see ‘em, ma’am,” Andrew declared. “But hey, I’ll get out of your hair now. See you on Sunday?”

“Yes, please. 6PM?”

“Count on it.” Grinning, he lifted his chin at Marshall. “Good to meet you, Mr. Vaughn.”

“Andrew,” said Marshall dryly, stooping to gather Moira’s luggage. He didn’t trouble to look up as the pilot called out a final salutation.

“Enjoy your weekend, Miss Birdie!”

“Thanks, Midas. You too.”

Glancing briefly at her pretty, red-lacquered toes, Marshall righted himself, bag secured over one shoulder, the handle of her wheeled case in his off hand. Moira watched him with an incriminating grin.

“That was entertaining…” he said, shifting the bag on his shoulder. “Miss Birdie.”

“Ooh! I hadn’t pegged you as the jealous type.”

“Everybody is the jealous type.” He nodded towards the waiting lounge. “But my concern is that you’re safe and happy.”

Smirking, she turned and led the way. “That’s very gentlemanly of you, Marshall. Thank you.”

“You’re welcome.”

He followed her across the tarmac, captivated by the rhythmic sway of her gait. He yanking the door open and securing it with a heel. Moira skittered past him, grabbing her hat reflexively as a rush of air flung her curls across her face and plastered her skirt against her backside. Marshall ducked in quickly, before the door could slam on him.

She tidied herself as she crossed the lobby, combing her mussed curls off her face with her fingers, face lit like a beacon in the waning sunlight. The main hall beyond looked out into a large cargo bay, where a crew of mechanics busied themselves tooling aircraft. One of the crewmen nudged his colleague, who glanced up to watch her walk by. The first offered commentary, eliciting a laugh from his partner, and they returned to their work grinning like jackals.

Apparently noting Marshall’s absence, Moira peered over her shoulder, and stopped herself mid-stride. She glanced at the men suspiciously, then back at him.

“Really, Marshall?”

Why should she be annoyed with him over the mechanics? Did she want him to go say something to them? He caught her up, frowning. “What?”

Scoffing, she cocked her head reproachfully. “That was a weird what.”

“What— it was just what.”

“What where you whatting about?”

“Moira.” He arched an eyebrow. “What?”

“Were you just scowling at those men?”

“What men—” he stumbled, but too late, and had to correct course. “No.”

“Ugh.” Sighing, she huffed her windblown curls off her face. “Don’t try to tell me this isn’t exactly what it looks like. Back when you were going on about safety and well-being and all that in chat… you weren’t just talking about during play, were you? You meant all the time.”

“I meant all the safety,” he clarified. “Sexual, physical, emotional. So, yes, all the—”

“Yeah ok, you’re very sweet. But are you really going to defend me against every single man who sneaks a peek at my ankles? Because that’ll get tedious really fast.”

Marshall scowled in admonishment. “All right, agency. Duly noted. That said, there is a difference between appreciating a beautiful woman and ogling her, Moira.”

“Uh-huh, sure. But you were just walking ten feet behind me, weren’t you? Watching my back, right?”

“I was appreciating.” Thin ice, maybe, but it was different. His intent wasn’t the same. And her demeanor was not befitting a submissive. “Also, watch your tone.”

“My tone.” Simmering, she lifted her chin imperiously. “Ok fine. Fair is fair, though…”

“Fair as in?” asked Marshall slowly.

“As in you walk ahead.” Shifting her weight to one foot, she crossed her arms and made a show of tracing his physique. “I want to appreciate you.”

If he weren’t annoyed by her impudent show of authority, he’d laugh. Part of him had to admit that it was kind of hot, and the other part of him wanted her to offer all that authority over to him.

“Submissives don’t give the commands, Moira,” at first, but quickly lost herself in the moment. Her smoldering eyes heated him at the collar.

“Marshall, are you blushing?”

He grinned wryly. “I don’t blush.”

“What do you call it then?”

“Riled.“

In a few hours, she’d be kneeling on the hardwood floor in Agness, her body mirrored in its gloss like Bougeureau’s Le Soir, toe tickling the face of the cool surf. The tender wrinkles of Moira’s feet, the soft swell of her bottom resting on her heels, the long, sensuous curve of her back.

“…from watching your dress glide over your hips…” he continued, meeting her heated look in full. Projecting his thoughts. “…and the back of your thighs. I fucking adore the sexy tick-tock of your ass while—”

“Ok, I got it!” she interrupted, cheeks flushing prettily.

“Moira,” he said gently, “are you blushing?”

“No! Stop that.”

“Fine. Shall we?” Offers his arm to walk side by side.

She looked at him expectantly.

“After you.”

She crossed the threshold, footsteps light, set her luggage down in the foyer very neatly, and stood waiting, hands folded in front of her.

“Take a walk around, get used to the place.”

“Aren’t you going to give me a tour?”

Mouths no. He wants her to feel free to explore. “I’ll be in the kitchen. Take your time.”

“Ok.” She pauses uncertainly. “Should I bring my things?”

“They’ll wait. Go find your room.”

She grimaces at him, but starts off walking through the place. She’s looking at the art, tracing her fingertips across the leather stitching of the calfskin sofa. He watches, mesmerized by her taking the place in.

She notices the first art piece that she likes. “Ooh, Vermeer. This is one of my favorites.”

He smiles knowingly.

She moves down the hall, and he watches her from the great room. Hallways have a way of emphasizing a woman’s shape. She finds the powder room and points it out. 

“Powder room.”

“Not your first rodeo.”

Curious himself, he decides to follow her through the house. The library, the solarium, and back into the dining room, where she pauses in front of another, smallish painting under a spotlight.

“I know this one, too.” She thinks. “Sacred Love and Profane Love. Giovanni…” She rolls her eyes in frustration. 

“Baglione. Did you know that’s Caravaggio’s face on the devil?”

“I did, yes.” She gestures out to the great room. “Vermeer, Baglione, and I saw Leighton, too… Chiaroscuro?”

“I have no idea what that means.”

“Calfskin sofas?”

“It’s very comfortable.”

“And turquoise Chinese vases? With brown peacocks. And red poppies.”

He shrugs.

She’s thoughtful, looking at all the things that he placed there for her. “This isn’t your home, is it?”

“It’s where I live.”

“It’s just a house, though. Not your home.”

“You haven’t found your room yet.”

“I’m guessing it’s east-facing with rose curtains.”

Later, she’s admiring the busts in the great room.

“Touch them.”

“Oh.” She’s surprised. That’s faux pas. She touches the bridge of Justine’s nose.

“People always touch the noses of statues.”

“Noses aren’t as intimate, I suppose.”

“True, I suppose.” Marshall moves behind Justine. He reaches over the bust’s shoulder and touches Moira’s nose. Intimately. “Is that not intimate?”

“Ok, yeah sure—”

“Where else do people touch statues?”

“I dunno, I guess the forehead.”

“Do it.”

She does, and he mirrors her movement, caressing her features as he does so. “I love the forehead. Just behind here is everything that is you. Every memory, every dream… every desire. Your mind… your name.”

She gives him a hot look.

“Where else?”

“How about—”

He places a finger over her lips, shushing her. “Where else.”

Moira gives him a look. She brushes her fingertips over Justine’s ear. Hot. He does the same. Down her neck, down the arch of the shoulder, to the shoulder bone, then back along the clavicle to the base of the neck.

“The bust stops here,” she smirks.

He delves her eyes with his own. “I don’t.” 

Slips his hand into her hair and emerges from behind the bust, pulling her close, until their faces are almost touching. “I mean to continue touching you,” he twists his grip, exposing her throat, “…in ways that require consent.”

“Ok…”

“May I continue?”

“Yeah.”

“Yes, Marshall.”

“Yes. Marshall.”

End with her placing the snow globe on the counter, quite conspicuously. He very noticed, and she stared at him intently, wondering if he was going to make a stink, but he let it be.

ToDo

“Do you always eat in twos?” asked Marshall, sipping Grenache.

Moira paused mid-fork. “What?”

“Four peas,” he said, gesturing with his chin.

“So?”

“You had three, and added a fourth before you took a bite.”

She scrutinized her fork briefly, and made a small noise of dismissal. “That doesn’t mean I was counting them, Marshall.”

“No?” he smirked. “Just a minute ago you had three almonds, and knocked one off.”

“Oh bullshit,” she laughed, and stuffed the peas in her mouth.

Marshall cocked an eyebrow. “Let’s find out shall we? For the rest of the meal, you’ll eat odd counts only.”

“What?”

“Only odd-numbered items on your fork. I’ll count your spoonfuls of soup, how many drinks of wine you take…” he gave her a playful grin. “Anything even-numbered adds to your count.”

“That’s stupid.”

“That’s three.”

She made a show of grumping, but her eyes sparkled.

Her first count had come in the car ride, when she’d asked how many women he’d slept with. He didn’t keep track of the number, and when she pressed for a guesstimate, he replied simply: “One”. She accused him of being coy, but he clarified that no, that was her count.

The second she’d gotten for slapping him on the ass while he was cooking. He let her off with a warning, but when she repeated the offense on her trip back through, he grabbed her and growled a count, explaining in no uncertain terms that the next would be punished severely and on the spot. She demurred, but not without pausing to consider whether it might be worth it.

Sipping her own Grenache, Moira flared her eyes at him. She cut a shrimp, speared it, and took a flourishing bite.

“That’s four,” said Marshall.

Moira scowled. “It was half a shrimp. That doesn’t count.”

“You cut it hemispherically,” he laughed. “Nobody does that. Tell the truth: you eat in twos.”

“That’s not it,” she protested. “It’s just… symmetry. People are hemispherical. Psychologically, physiologically.” She gave him a pointed grin. “All our parts come in twos.”

“I can think of a few exceptions.”

“All the best parts.”

“Except the exceptions,” he jockeyed.

Her next bites added two more quick counts, and the laughing admission that yes, she did in fact eat in twos. By the end her count was eight, but Marshall was pleased to see her visibly intent on complying with the rules.

His housekeeper didn’t work weekends, which suited his needs perfectly. It was 9:26, and he was eager to get started, so he made quick work of flinging everything into the dishwasher while Moira leaned on the island counter, happily picking matching pairs of M&Ms out of a bowl of trail mix and tossing them in her mouth.

The steady, interminable tocking of the grandfather clock filled the empty house. Fifty one hours remaining. Three thousand sixty minutes. In other words, für immer, pour toujours, per sempre, aeternum. For-fucking-ever.

Pinching the bridge of his nose and grimacing, Marshall plopped the book he’d not been reading for the last forty three minutes on the coffee table, next to an untouched snifter of bourbon. He sat forward, elbows on his knees, and laced his fingers together in front of his lips, staring past the soaring bay windows to the receding sun kissing the spikes of conifer on the far ridge.

Nearly silhouetted against the Oregon sky, Josephine and Juliet gazed back at him. Somehow neither of them ever fully met his eyes, even when he stood directly in their line of sight. Hedy had walked in on him trying to figure it out.

“What’s wrong?” she asked.

“No matter where I stand…” he replied distractedly, shifting his feet a few inches, “they don’t seem to look at you. They’re like anti-Mona Lisas.”

Hedy scoffed at first, then realized he wasn’t joking. “Uh… they don’t have pupils, Mr. Jones.”

Scowling, he’d given it up and walked away, tempted to turn with each step and double check. He’d tried a few more times since then, to no avail.

All of the furniture and deco had arrived, and Hedy had flown in for a few days to arrange everything. It was refreshing to have her there, her pixie laugh filling whatever room she was working in, enlisting him to move the heavy stuff, testing art hangings to the millimeter, and bickering over the placement of the Malm fireplaces. Marshall won the argument with a bribe —a full course dinner, for which she had picked the menu— and was all the happier for having her stay. They sipped wine on the deck and chatted late into the evening about the Pre-Raphaelites, Gertrude Stein, the curious story of absinthe, and the harmonious blending of ethnicities around the world as seen from orbit.

She flew out early the following morning, mildly hungover, leaving him with a breathtakingly sophisticated home worthy of Dwell magazine. A majestic Schonbek chandelier sparkled in the dining room, lights mirrored on the glass surface and the gleaming wood floor. Etc.

But quiet.

Digging the remote out from beneath the discarded book, he flipped through his playlists, searching for something to fit his mood. He skipped over big band, frowned at jazz, and eventually settled on Lana. 

Closing his eyes, he sank back into the sofa, letting her sultry butter voice seep through him. Lana transported him, erotic prose ebbing from her lips, inebriating the air like smooth molasses rum. His bike was still at the shop being resurrected, and he was no fan of running, and what did it matter, any of them would just be another distraction. Don’t try to change what you can’t control, don’t waste energy on unsolvable problems. You can’t stop the sun. What he’d been referring to at the time was the futile act of worrying. It solved nothing, it only wasted time. Either take action, address the issue head-on, or, if you cannot act, put it aside.

Marshall’s worry crystallized. He killed the music, stomped into the kitchen, and snatched up his phone.

A soft-bellied, white-haired teddy bear of a man, Jay Kinsley had retired from the Bureau seven years ago to attend to his wife, Gloria, who’d been diagnosed with ovarian cancer. He was a bona fide genius in front of a computer, almost single-handedly architecting the Witness Protection Program databases, and still knew them better than anybody in the entire high security wing of the J. Edgar Hoover building. Towards the end of his tenure, Jay spent most of his time in Mahogany Row, soothing the cyber concerns of foreign officials. Unofficially KMA, slang for an agent still active past retirement, he was often brought in as a consultant to assist with sticky issues, and it was under such circumstances that he and Marshall made acquaintance.

A Georgia Senator, Ander Bolman, then a Presidential candidate, had been linked to funds being sent to an undisclosed recipient overseas. Three separate Bureau departments had gotten involved, and Marshall had become a target. Jay managed to clean it all up without anybody getting ousted, arrested, or shot, in the process becoming one of four people in the world who knew Marshall’s real name.

If anybody could figure out what Anka was up to, it was him.

He answered on the second ring. “JR! This is out of the blue, you better not be in trouble.”

“I’m well, Jay, thanks,” said Marshall acerbically. “You got a minute?”

“Was just on my way out, but I got ten if you need ‘em.”

And did he really want to involve himself? He’d tried so hard to leave it all in Italy, to move on and start over. Reinvent himself. He didn’t need the complications, and Moira specifically didn’t want any.

But what if this was his only opportunity? What if something happened while he sat on his hands, second-guessing…

“JR,” coaxed Jay, “I can feel the tension from the other side of the country. What’s up buddy?”

“I don’t know,” Marshall frowned. “I’m wired up. Nearly broke my damn leg fleeing a helicopter on my bike last week. And I saw-”

“What helicopter?”

“It was nothing, Jay. It was stupid. I couldn’t see what it was at first, but then I saw an emblem on the side, and— nevermind, that isn’t why I called anyway.”

“You’re working yourself up,” said Jay reassuringly. “There’s nothing to worry about, ok? You’re dark. Nobody’s looking for you, and even if they were, they wouldn’t be sending out attack choppers. The good Senator doesn’t have that level of clearance, anyway. Sorry to break it to you, buddy, but you’re small potatoes.”

“Hm,” said Marshall again, annoyed with himself for bristling at that notion. “Well that’s good, I guess.”

That’s very good, yes.” Jay chuckled. “So if that wasn’t why you called, what was?”

Tapping his fingers on the white marble, Marshall sighed. The metallic jingle of keys rang through clearly through the phone; Jay had just set them down on his kitchen table.

They had sat there together many times, the dark, charactered wood smooth under Marshall’s fingertips, stoic and strong through the four generations of Kinsleys that had passed it down. No matter how good or bad the coffee, it always tasted better at the Kinsley table.

“All right,” said Jay. “Something’s seriously up, you got my ear. Now stop making me ask you. What’s the scoop?”

Marshall combed his forelock off his head. No getting out of it now, he’d have to give a legitimate reason for his call. The old man wasn’t one to be deterred when he set his mind to something, and he could spot a ventriloquist fibbing with the lights off.

“I need you to look into somebody for me.”

“A background check? Already?” Jay asked, alarmed. “Wait, did something happen with Miss Berthelsen?”

“No no, she’s fine. She’s great.” Marshall shifted the phone to his other ear, preparing himself. “It’s not a client, it’s… an old friend.”
